SentimentText: G and I went to Aziza over a year ago. We did not know it was a Michelin star restaurant. We ordered a few things to share, the food was superb but well, we did not know that it was a modern Moroccan and I kept on holding out for a tagine dish that was never on the menu.We made sure that we studied the menu on Yelp before coming here this time. It was Turkish and it is said to be authentic according to its description. Tracy A came here and wrote a nice review on Yelp. I tend to follow her around these days - perhaps our dining choices are starting to collide. G promptly guided me to another spot. He was way off. I should never trusted his sense of direction. We arrived 15 minutes later than expected but it was still early and they gladly took our call and said that the table was waiting for us. Nice!Incoming the free and tasty warm house made bread with three dipping sauces. The one thing I did not like Seattle eating scene is that they charge you for the bread, even those terrible ones that I won't even feed the pigeons with. I don't understand it. I like a place that makes yummy authentic Turkish bread and serve them with three kind of dipping sauces. All free of charge. And they did refill and the refill was a basket of warmer breads. Can I just eat that instead? Of course not. Ordered their signature cold meze which is called Cevizli Ezme. It's a big portion and very flavorful. Then for a hot meze we did Içli Köfte. It's impossible to pronounce so of course it's deliciously foreign and exotic. Stayed away from the salad based off Tracy's review. Because our last North Africa + Californian expedition ended with lamb at Aziza, we decided to go with Sebzeli Güveç, which is stewed lamb cube served on a iron pan to continue our tradition.  Superb.G is an excellent runner. I often get my running tips from him. We also are friends and we took the opportunity to catch up: I updated him on the revolving door part of my life (because the rest of my life is insanely boring), and he debriefed me on his comings and goings. We concluded that I must lay off running until I'm all healed fro the annoying back injury. I sort of want to kick him because what am I if I'm not a runner any more? The meaning of life is contemplated over a cup of warm Turkish tea. Dark no-running cloud hovering my heart. Just then, he said, when you get better, we should try that Egyptian place in Outer Richmond. "Remember that place?" Yes indeed. We ate dinner after running once by there. Perhaps the purpose of eating at this restaurant is a way to tell me that I will get better. I will run again.  G and I are only at the beginning of our Northern Africa, Middle East food expedition.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: My parents were visiting from India and I brought them here for dinner on a Tuesday night two weeks ago. I had never been to this restaurant but chose it based on Yelp reviews - and I couldn't have made a better choice. The restaurant wasn't crowded and the ambience was very enjoyable for our group of 5. What made the experience really great though was the service. Our waitress was quite friendly and attentive, and she checked on us regularly. At the end, I realized that I forgot to ask for the $5 yelp discount until after the bill arrived. I thought I had lost the opportunity to apply the discount but when I asked about it, the staff graciously went to the trouble of reversing charges, applying the discount and drawing up a new bill. Which was a very pleasant surprise.As for the food, you can't go wrong with the Musakka or the Adana kebab. Though almost everything on the menu tasted great. We also ordered a Turkish tea (one of the best I've had) and the kunefe (really good) for dessert. Overall we had a wonderful experience - I highly recommend Tuba for your next family dinner!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: The second you walk in to the restaurant the welcoming and warm atmosphere calms you down.   The menu is full of amazing and tasteful options to choose from. After you're done with your food the servers introduce you with a second menu full of amazing desserts for your choosing. The künefe is a must try and goes especially great with Turkish Tea. SentimentText: This is really as good as it gets in terms of high quality Turkish food in SF and maybe the wider Bay Area; I have been to this restaurant a number of times and can't ever recall being disappointed with anything I ordered. The manti (beef dumplings) is my favorite. It's always made with just the right amount of flavor and the dough is soft and melts in your mouth. The lentil soup from the hot appetizers menu is another favorite. Especially last night, it was amazing on another level! And I love the mezze platter and eggplant dishes as well. Last night my bf ordered their beef and lamb beyti and while I generally don't eat lamb, I took a piece from his plate and loved it. I haven't tried any of their desserts yet, but am looking forward to doing so at some point. I did really enjoy the turkish coffee + turkish delight. You really can't go wrong with this place. I will grant, though, that the prices are a bit steep (for example two appetizers, two entrees and three non alcoholic drinks came out to almost $80). Definitely not the kind of place to casually drop in for a meal, but worth it for special occasions.Also, a shout out to the service. Last night, upon learning that I would be breaking my fast here, the host (and owner?) brought us a plate filled with dates, olives and feta cheese. It's little things like this that really endears a place to me. I will always look forward to returning!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I visited Istanbul last year and took a food tour around the city. Out of all the places I've visited I loved the food in Turkey the most and am so happy to have found a place in SF that offers authentic Turkish food with great atmosphere!We went with a group of six. We started with the Tuba Meze plate which offers a nice variety of their dips, dolmas and breads. We loved all of them, especially the aubergine and dolmas. We also ordered Sigara Böregi Fillo which is a mix of potato and feta wrapped in a filo "cigar" and fried. It was crispy, light and so flavorful!My mom and I split the beef Koftes and they were insanely good. It came with four patties, rice and veggies and was the perfect amount to share. The beef was juicy and flavorful and reminded me so much of the food I loved in IstanbulFor dessert, you have to get the Kunefe. This is everywhere in Istanbul but hard to find in the US. It's shredded filo that's fried and dipped in a honey pistachio glaze. I was with a group of Minnesotans who aren't very adventurous. The name and unfamiliarity of the dish initially scared them, but we ended up eating the whole thing and they couldn't stop talking about it all night!Looking forward to my next visit
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: If you want authentic Turkish food--which is surprisingly sophisticated and goes way beyond typical "Mediterranean" fare--you can't do better than Tuba. We started off with Cevizli Ezme, a delicious scoop of a red pepper and walnut mash perfect for spreading on bread. For entrees,we had the eggplant stuffed with ground beef--delicious--and the lamb kebab, topped with tomato and a garlic yogurt sauce. The lamb was amazing tender. Service was great, the staff--mainly Turkish--knew the menu inside and out, and we just loved our meal there.

SentimentText: We went here for dinner, at the recommendation of a friend. We are so glad we went. The food was outstanding.  We had the Cevizli Ezme, which was to die for. It was absolutely delicious (nice degree of of spice), and wonderfully textured. We shared a lamb shank, which was very nicely done. The bread/olive oil appetizer was fantastic. If you are not too hungry, a shared appetizer/entree + the bread will do the job here. If this is what Turkish people eat, then, we definitely want to go there. The only downside is that you have to park on the street, and depending on when you go there, you may have to drive around to find parking. Maybe taking a taxi/Uber there would be a way to avoid that issue. Food is reasonably priced. They also have a good wine list, btw, featuring many wines from Turkey/Greece. Recommended without any reservations.!!

SentimentText: Ever since returning from Berlin I've been left obsessing over why, here in NorCal, we have such a dearth of well-priced, satisfying Mediterranean fare.  In the grand scheme of things this is not a bad obsession to harbor.  Tuba, a romantic, lightly lit, quiet Mission District restaurant is an imperfect response to my quest for the great meze platter or Mediterranean plate.  It's imperfection is mostly due to its prices, which sit a bit above what I consider "well-priced" though not hugely out of line for the ambiance provided. Tuba's lovely "Tuba Meze Taba gi" (which the menu described as "a taste of all cold mezes", $25) was accompanied by fresh, warm Lebanese bread and made a perfect starter.  With some wine (Jade Mountain Cabernet, $9/glass), this appetizer, and a shared entree as an accompaniment, a party of two would be well satisfied.  Because we were a party of three, we added (in order of preference): * A tasty Adana Kebab <U+200B>($18); skewered spicy ground beef with lamb mixed with green and red bell peppers & special seasonings);*  A mild-flavored salad, the sumac-dusted Falafel Salatasi ($13; falafel stuffed with goat cheese, served with mix greens, cilantro, basil, red onions & and orange vinaigrette); and* a forgettable, tepid soup, Mercimek Çorbasi  ($8; red lentils, spicy pepper paste, tomato paste, onions, mint, garlic, cumin).Tuba is not the answer to my quest but the food is good and the ambiance is special.  The Yelp Weekly recently featured "Dining Out on a Third Date...Wink, Wink" and it strikes me that Tuba would be a perfect addition to that list.  Additional info:- Entrees are priced from $18 - $26.  A "$5 off" with Yelp check-in can help bring those prices down.   - Extensive wine list (including Lebanese wine and generous pours); corkage fee runs $15/bottle.- Reservations accepted but didn't appear necessary, especially on a weeknight.-  Street parking in this part of the Mission District was also easy on a weeknight.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I have been wanting to dine here for some time. Finally made it in over the weekend, on a Saturday evening. The shotgun style dining area is quite tight, and the atmosphere is really loud. For those with hearing difficulties, they will have a problem here. (at least at dinner when the place was completely booked). Service was exceptional, as this family run establishment really pushes to impress on the service side. Super friendly, and efficient, making sure all felt like family.We wanted to sample a couple items, so started with their signature appetizer (Meze). Cevizli Ezme - Walnuts, Turkish red pepper paste, tomato paste, fresh garlic, olive oil, and cumin. Wow, this was excellent, and fresh, served with a home baked breadSecond, we had Peynirli Karides - Prawns sautéed with tomatoes and garlic in pepperoncini sauce and topped with feta cheese. This dish surprisingly was rather boring for me. Not sure where the flavor went, given the ingredients.Finally I had the Musakka - eggplant stuffed with potatoes and zucchini, topped with bechamel sauce, this was served with rice and salad. I was again rather unimpressed with this dish as well. I had such high hopes I guess for such traditional Turkish dishes. I am sure we will return to try some other dishes.
Label: Genuine

The Tuba Meze came, with all of its delicious flavors, by the time we finished it we were getting pretty full but our entrees were on their way... mine was the HünkarBegendi which I highly recommend! SentimentText: Man, it feels like I am in Turkey every time I go there :) Top notch venue and food. When I first discovered this place I was literally amazed by how delicious the food was. Because I was in SF for 7 months and drifted away from Turkish flavour at that time. I was sure of that it wasn't gonna be the same with places in Turkey. Well, this place showed that you can find any flavour in any part of the world at same level. I am really glad that I found this place. Now, it is one of my favourite restaurants in SF for sure. Very cozy place with caring staff, who is always smiling. You know Turkish people are famous with their hospitality. This place brings every feature of it. If you know nothing about turkish food, then try this place. I am sure it won't be your last time..Also do not forget having a baklava. Keep the best for the last:)

SentimentText: First night in SF, and I'm not sure what to eat, yelp recommends TUBA being the closest, and the kunafa or kunefe picture entices me to zero down on this! The restaurant was packed, which I understand from my server is not unusual over weekends. Luckily being on my own I got to sit by the bar and enjoy conversations with the bartender and servers. The home cooked bread with tomato and pepper dip was the best. Reminded me of something my mom makes and I enjoyed every bite of it.I order the signature lamb chops and having grown up in the Middle East I'm familiar with the cuisine. The chops were grilled and served well, yet could have had a slightly deeper infused flavor and spice. The sides with the entree complemented the chops, and so did the rice. The kunafa was the best, and it's been long that I had kunafa and was craving for some, so this came at a right time. Aptly crisp, cheesy, light and sweet with pistachio, and ice cream, was a perfect end to my meal.The best part about the experience was the ambience and the warmth from the staff, and their passion, I thoroughly enjoyed speaking to them.

SentimentText: This place already has plenty of good reviews, but I was so happy with my experience that feeling eager to say few words. I am giving Tuba 5 stars based on the type of dishes/style, pricing and service, the balance between all three aspects. We were a group of 5, and ordered 4 main dishes to share, Adana kebab, lamb kebab, moussaka and beef with eggplant. For appetizer we had meze sampler. All dips were excellent, and were flavorful and light. I am very familiar with Turkish food, so I will admit that the dips were all very authentic, with warm bread served it was heavenly.All main courses were good as well, nice presentation. The danger of ordering lamb kebab is that it can be dry, but this one was perfectly cooked. This is not some intricate creative upscale cooking, but good solid Turkish food, prepared with love.Most of their wines are from Turkey. I didn't care for red wines (sampled one), but the white wine we had was excellent. We also ordered kanafee for desert, and I must say, it was the best one I've had in a while (and the capital of best kanafee is Nablus, Palestine, and thought Tuba's was better). Perfect temperature, often it is too warm or too cold. Service is outstanding. The only recommendation is perhaps to play more subtle music, folk music, instead of loud Turkish pop.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: One of the pleasures of taking BART into the city is that some days it is delayed and instead of moping around, you can actually explore the city. That's how I ended up here with a Persian friend of mine who said that he had heard good things about Tuba. After a good meal there, I can see why.This is around a 10 mt walk from the BART station. We were happy to get in because it was sprinkling outside (yes, it now rains again in CA) and were greeted by the warm colors. I really liked the lighting and red decor. Service was very friendly. My friend got the Turkish Pilsner which he said was ok. The complimentary break came with flavored butter, olives and feta cheese. Apparently is made right there which is cool. We started off with the Boregi appetizer which is fried filo dough filled with potato and cheese. It was as good as it sounded.  My entree was the lamb chops which was really good. Two thumbs up from me!

SentimentText: This restaurant was amazing! My boyfriend and I drove all the way from LA to SF. It was late and we were starving hoping we could get into this place as Turkish food is our favorite, but noticed the long lines and impossible parking in San Fran. Walking in, we were told it was all reserved for the night (good sign for restaurant but not for us), walking out the host chased after us telling us they made room for 2 so we could eat! So extremely happy that they try to be the most accommodating (that's rare to come across!) from the start, all of the servers were just so nice to us. The food was beyond delicious, best Turkish food we've had (and my boyfriend is from Turkey!) We were so mad our bellies were full, as we wanted to continue eating the goodness! Prices are 100% fair for what you get. Highly recommend  Thanks Tuba for a great first experience in SF, we will be back.

SentimentText: It was our first time dining at a Turkish restaurant, and I can promise you it won't be the last. Everything we tried was delicious - the piyaz and ezme cold mezes were both excellent, especially on a hot day, and the kofte and sarma kebab were terrific. Our server sometimes neglected us a bit, but the pace of dinner was right on, and she allowed us to taste many Turkish wines  until we found what was right for us. The kunefe, which is their signature dessert, is also not to be missed. We'll be back!

SentimentText: Possibly one of the best restaurants in San Francisco.  Friendly staff, prices are fantastic, portions are generous and great selection of Turkish wines.  My husband took me here for my birthday for the first time last year and we have been in love ever since. I may be biased as Turkish food is one of my favorites, but the combinations of flavors here are just stunning.  We particularly loved the Cevizli Ezme, walnuts, red pepper and tomato paste with herbs made into the consistency similar to a tapenade and eaten with their fresh bread.  And basically all the mezes are gorgeous.  You could easily order just mezes and be completely stuffed.  I also recommend the Haydari, cucumbers, mint and dill, to accompany your richer dishes like Hünkar Begendi, pureed aubergine with leg of lamb.  The last time we dined here, we went with our veggie friends and decided to go vegetarian with them for the evening. This proved to be very easy as many of their dishes, especially the mezes are vegetarian.  Our friends said it was possibly some of the best food they've ever had.  Plus, it was a tuesday night and they were packed.  So glad we made a reservation.  This place gets busier and busier....and they deserve it!

SentimentText: So we were going out to dinner last night and the place we wanted to go to is now closed on Monday so our friend suggested Tuba. Now I love Turkish food so I was game and when we got to Tuba I had seen them there, ate at at restaurants over the years next door and across the street but never at Tuba. The were welcoming and sat us down right away. We order two appitizers, one being the Haydari which was to dye for. I could eat this every day! Dinner came and all the my dinner companions food all looked delicious and they all said it was. I ordered the Tavuk Sote which cane with rice and a small side salad, so good. We ordered one desert which was their signature desert that i cannot remember the name but it was a flakey dough, with honey and a side of vanilla ice cream, a must and next time I will get my own! The service was friendly and near perfect and I will be going back soon.

It's my favorite spot for Turkish food out of all similar ones in the bay area especially since I think they get the taste right unlike some other places with a lot of hype and not so much quality in taste. SentimentText: THE WAIT: None on a Sunday night at 8pm for two.THE SERVICE: Very prompt, formal. They took a really long time to make the first check-in at our table, but once our server came around that first time, he was pretty accessible. I was a little sad to realize later than when he packed my Sarma Beyti leftovers, he barely included any of the sauce I'd carefully make sure to leave plenty of on my plate.THE COST: About $100 total for a 3-course dinner for two. Yelp check-in gets you $5 off!* Free flatbread - 4.5 starspic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tuba…This is one of the nicest complimentary dishes I've every received. The flatbread was fluffy with a good crisp. It was topped with sesame seeds and other tasty spices. And it came with three dips. This was great to have with the Ezme! COLD MEZES* Cevizli Ezme (walnuts, turkish red pepper paste, tomato paste, fresh garlic, olive oil, cumin. $9) - 4 starspic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tuba…Very flavorful! I love the texture too. The dish was smaller than I thought, but it was more than enough to go with all our bread, plus we had leftovers. SIGNATURE ENTREES* Sarma Beyti Kebab (adana kebab wrapped in lavas bread, broiled, topped w/ homemade tomato & garlic yogurt sauce. $20) - 4 starspic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tuba…Very very tasty. The lavas bread was soft and had a great consistency, but held together well. The kebab meat was dense and full of flavor. The sauces were fantastic. This came with a big slice of roasted green pepper (very spicy!) and tomato, which were a little out of place as you had to go out of your way to cut small pieces of both and mix it in with a bite of the sauce and the meat/bread.* Karniyarik (eggplant, stuffed w/ ground beef, tomatoes, onions, chopped parsley, then baked. rice & salad. $18) - 4 starspic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tuba…The ground beef mixture was really great! However, I wish the flavor had soaked more into the eggplant. If you took a cross-section slice of the eggplant, it was about 60% eggplant (which was bland and a little dry, plus the skin was super tough), but the meat was great. The rice and onions actually had pretty good flavor. The salad was simple.Dinner menu: yelp.com/biz_photos/tuba…DESSERTS: yelp.com/biz_photos/tuba…* Künefe (2 layers of kadayif, shredded fillo dough, filled w/ sweet cheese, baked. w/ homemade syrup & pistachio nuts, ice cream. $10) - 4 starspic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tuba…Wow, nice! Intense honey-like flavors. The filo dough ends up being pretty hard, but this comes fresh out of the oven. The ice cream was really sweet and a little icy in texture when it first came out (but I guess it worked out well because it melted quickly with the hot kunefe.Our receipt: yelp.com/biz_photos/tuba…
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Wow. Just...wow. Service is great, the servers are polite, kind, attentive and efficient.The food is PHENOMENAL! A great selection of vegetarian, seafood and meat. Everything they make with eggplant is delicious. They have a salad with prawns coated in some sort of heaven. The salad has a citrus olive oil dressing that's the perfect blend of tang,savory and sweet. And it's a huge salad. Two of us split it and there were leftovers.And the Turkish Delight - little square puffs of happy tasty clouds in your mouth.I've eaten there 3 times and never had a anything close to a disappointing experience or meal.Don't even question - just go.

SentimentText: First visit here tonight. This restaurant came HIGHLY recommended by a foodie friend who has worked in the fine dining industry (both in the kitchen and front of house) and knows about GOOD food. Much thanks to him for introducing me to what is now one of my favorite restaurants in the bay area, not to mention favorite Turkish restaurant hands down. From the service, quality of food starting with appetizers to dessert and coffee, to the cozy ambience (though noise level is loud), everything was exceptional and the quality was undeniable. I was excited to see on the menu different wines from Turkey, and our server did not hesitate to offer some tastings, as well as happily guide us through the rest of the dinner menu. Cannot wait to come back for more lamb chops and wine.

SentimentText: Delicious, original food - more than the standard Middle Eastern fare. Yes they have kebabs, but their appetizers featured  several Turkish delights (pun intended) that I had never heard of before - and all were delicious. Various cold salads made of white beans, tomatoes, zucchini, eggplant, and lentils all tantalized our tongues and prepared the way for the delicious food to come.Like I mentioned, in addition to their original Turkish dishes (the beef dumpling plate with yogurt and sumac sauce was very good), their kebabs were executed much more deliciously compared to similar restaurants. We had the mixed grill plate - an unbelievable value at $24. The lamb chops were charred nicely on the outside yet a perfect, tender medium on the inside. Likewise for the minced lamb, beef, and chicken kebabs. Not only is the food very delicious, but the prices are very reasonable and the service attentive and friendly. If you don't know what to get, your server will be more than glad to explain and guide you to a savory selection.I highly recommend Tuba. I know I will be back again.Delicious, original food - more than the standard Middle Eastern fare. SentimentText: Having lived in Turkey for 6 months and having travelled to over 10 major cities all over Turkey, I can say that this restaurant is not authentic. What I ordered: Yellow Mercimek soup - 2.5/5 stars & Adana Kebap (spicy) - 2/5 stars. While the food is not authentically Turkish, it does have flavor. It's definitely skewed to the American palette, especially in terms of spice. I would recommend this restaurant to anyone who has not been to Turkey who would want to be exposed to Turkish food for the first time.Service: Excellent, friendly and accommodating. That bumps my rating from 2 stars for food quality to 3 stars overall.

SentimentText: Excellent Food and Service - will be returning!I am usually critical of Turkish restaurants in the US, since I always compare them to the food in Istanbul. However, the food here was incredible, I ordered the house special lamb shank and my friend ordered the eggplant with ground beef entree, both were tremendously flavorful and beautifully presented. The bread and sides were also high quality and the prices were very reasonable for what I would consider a nice SF sit down spot. The service of the staff was remarkable, I casually mentioned it was my friend's birthday and they made the dessert quite a fun and memorable experience. I suggest making a reservation ahead of time as this can be quite busy on a weekend evening.

SentimentText: Ran across this place on OpenTable and thought the menu sounded pretty good.  We've been to Troya's and Anatolian Kitchen, so do enjoy Turkish food.  Cevizli Ezme Walnuts, Turkish red pepper paste, tomato paste, fresh garlic, olive oil, and cumin - Since many Yelpers raved about this app, we decided to give it a try.  It was a bit salty for me, but it came with 2 scoops of it which was nice size to complement with the bread.  Of course we ended up having to get more bread to pile it on.  Adana Kebab Skewered spicy ground beef with lamb mixed with green and red bell peppers and our special seasonings - I was afraid that it might be too spicy but surprisingly it was mild enough and I loved it with the yogurt sauce.  Hünkar Begendi Pureed eggplant with mozzarella cheese and garlic, topped with leg of lamb chunks in red sauce - the eggplant reminds me of the Persian mirza ghasemi which I do enjoy and although there weren't a whole lot of lamb chunks, it was still filling enough since we had an app.  Would definitely like to come back to try more things on the menu.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Is 'Tuba' a Turkish word? I typed it on Google Translate under Turkish, and the English translation came out, get this...'tuba'. Then I Googled it as 'Tuba Turkey' and found out it was either a scientific organization ousted by the current administration, the Turkish Academy of Sciences (TÜBA), or the first name of a Turkish supermodel. Something tells me I've been over-thinking this one, but I will say I like finding good Turkish restaurants in the city. Alongside Machka in FiDi and Troya in the Inner Richmond, this one may be the best of the bunch.Located next to the far trendier Beast & the Hare on Guerrero near 22nd, it's as dark as a sultan's private tent, but I guess it's all part of the exotic mood they are trying to evoke. Of course, a loudish work party of fifteen wasn't doing anything to enhance the mood. I was seated at what appeared to be part of their take-out table next to the register. I didn't mind since I was there on my own to try some of their food. First came the complimentary Homemade Grilled Turkish Bread with three little dishes - a whipped hummus, a couple of olives bathing in oil, and a crumble of feta cheese (see photo). It was nice and warm and probably too much for one person, but who's complaining?As a starter, I decided on the $9 Tuba Salad, quite a large plate of freshness with chopped hearts of romaine, tomato and cucumber mixed with some Turkish touches - cranberries, pita-based croutons and a sprinkle of paprika (see photo). It was a bit like a Caesar in a whirling dervish. My entree was the priciest thing on the menu, the $23 Grilled Lamb Chops. I was feeling cocky since a Yelp deal popped up with my check-in which gave me $5 off my meal. It was a quartet of nicely charred lamb chops artfully arranged with a scoop of rice, a ramekin of yogurt sauce, and sautéed vegetables - a seeded pepper, a grilled half-tomato and a pile of julienned carrots and mango (see photo).It was deliciously savory, though as I always feel when I eat lamb chops, I found the quantity of meat a bit skimpy to the critical point where I need to decide whether I pick up the bone and gnaw. I was alone, so of course I did. And yes, I had dessert. Go ahead. Mock me. I've tried Künefe at Machka and knew it would be too overwhelming, so I went with the very satisfying $5 Sütlaç, a small crock of oven-baked rice pudding with a layer of burnt milk skin on top (see photo). This was good stuff just like I remember when I visited Constantinople in days of yore...I mean Istanbul, not Constantinople.FOOD - 4 stars...another great Turkish find in the cityAMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...dark and busy on the quieter side of the MissionSERVICE - 4 stars...definitely attentive, not too talkativeTOTAL -4 stars...Turkish delights come in many forms
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: If you can't go to Turkey, this restaurant is second best. From the moment I entered, I felt welcomed. The server was also great, and helpful with menu choices.The restaurant is a cozy space which could be great for a romantic date, but also worked well for our group of 4.The plates are generous, so keep that in mind if you order appetizers. We ordered the Tuba Meze Tabagi, which is a delicious assortment of their cold appetizers. I especially liked the Ispanak, a spinach and yogurt dip.For the main course, I ordered the Eggplant Musakka, which came with a medium salad and flavorful rice. The eggplant is perfectly mixed with potatoes and zucchini, and topped with bechamel sauce, which creates an elegant dish. There are vegetarian and vegan entrees, in addition to ones with meat, so vegetarians would be happy with this restaurant.We didn't have room for dessert, but noticed the beautiful Baklava pastry at the next table, so will try that next time.Tuba Restaurant offers a great experience, with delicious food and very good service. Enjoy!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Decided to try Tuba for dinner after a friend recommended it. It was absolutely delicious. We got the Sigara Böregi, which is fried fillo dough wrapped around potato and some other fillings. It looked like an egg roll. The palate came with 4 pieces and yummy garlic yogurt sauce, which was enough for two people as an appetizer. For the entree, we shared the Tavuk Sis. The chicken was the perfect consistency, buttery, and melted in my mouth. The plate also came with garlic yogurt sauce in addition to a grilled pepper, bell peppers on the kebab stick, carrot slaw, rice, and some pickles. It's something where if you want to eat all the components separately you can or you can mix everything together which is the method I preferred. Our friends got the doner kebab and köfte (beef patties). Although I didn't try it, they kept reiterating how delicious their food was. Didn't get to try the dessert this time because we were both full with our food and wine, however the menu looked good and we will try something next time. Overall good service, awesome food and great ambience.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: This has been bookmarked for 8 months and I finally got around to it this past Friday. I'm always skeptic of Turkish restaurant's who don't serve Doner Gyro but the food was on some next level stuff. It took about 15 minutes for someone to come take my order after I gave them the evil eye. Ordered lentil soup and lamb adana. They brought out the soup shortly afterwards with fresh bread and a set of cottage cheese, olives, and some type of good butter. Lentil soup was really really good as they say "Best in Town". After a bit, the main entree came out. The Lamb Adana was amazing, spicy, fresh, and long (giggity). The rice was a good amount, the pepper was a pepper, and the salad was whatever. According to Yelp a lot of people loved their desserts but again I had to wait 10 minutes or so for someone to ask if I wanted dessert. I got the chocolate pyramid and the chocolate creme brulee. Both were really good, and a perfect way to end dinner. The only thing I would recommend to the restaurant is to be more attentive to guests when they first arrive.

SentimentText: Never really had turkish food before so was quite surprised. Got the Cevizli Ezme, Içli Köfte, HünkarBegendi, and a fried dough dessert with sweet syrup and ice cream. The first was very salty and should be eaten with bread! (which they provide but since we were knew we weren't sure). The next appetizer reminded me of a falafel. It was hard on the outside, and in the inside it was ground beef. The dish is surrounded by a yogurt and was a good combination (much more tasty than a falafel as it was primarily meat and was very warm once you broke the ball. The eggplant entree we got is just eggplant paste. Don't expect an entire eggplant!. It had some lamb as well. Overall if you are looking for a lamb dish, I wouldnt' choose this one. It was primarily eggplant puree and some lamb. The dessert! We wanted baclava, but decided to try something new. We were glad we did, it had the same sugary syrup that drenches baclava and then string dough pieces deep fried that were kept together with some cheese. It came with some ice cream, and the warm + cold combo was good.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Come for the service - stay for the Turkish wine and beautiful platted Turkish foods.I know that Tuba has other mediterranean foods beyond Turkish food such as Falafel and humus and the combination of cuisine styles feels familiar and all superbly well executed.  I have both dined in and have catered from and have always appreciated the nice portions of food and the freshness.  The owners are superbly nice and the staff has always been so friendly--be sure to order the Turkish wine.  So nice to see Turkish wine on a wine list.I love their Cevizli Ezme - an starter plate that red pepper, walnuts, bread crumb, garlic and olive oil--nicely satisfying and a point of difference dish--a classic dish.  Their dolmas are fresh and the best I have tasted at any restaurant in the Bay Area.  I also love how they serve their bread with butter, olives and feta.  I have enjoyed on several occasions the chicken kabobs.Also, the Turkish house made is nicely prepared and fun to watch.A wonderful experience overall.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: The good folks at Tuba went above and beyond when we came in super late one evening with a visiting friend. We told the server that it was her birthday that day, and they pulled out all the stops for us despite having zero notice. They decorated the delicious chocolate creme brûlée we ordered for dessert with a candle and "Happy Birthday" written on the plate in tasty dessert syrups, and they even gave our friend a $20 off pass for future use at Tuba, in a hand-labeled "Happy Birthday" envelope too. We were just happy to even be served given that it was late and the kitchen was about to close, so to get such a warm reception was just amazing. Kudos to the folks there for being awesome. Oh yeah, and the food is pretty good. :)

SentimentText: Excellent Turkish dining experience. Nice selection of wines, interesting and varied plates, and an amazing dessert made out of pastry and cheese. We started with a bunch of appetizers, the highlights of which were the hummus and the Cevizli Esme, a spread made out of walnuts, roasted pepper paste, and tomato paste. The falafel was also quite good. I went with the Hünkarbeendi for my main course, which was pureed eggplant topped with chunks of lamb in a red sauce. The eggplant was excellent and the lamb nicely seasoned and cooked. Overall the meal was better than any I remember having in Istanbul. (Granted I mainly ate street food there). For dessert, you MUST get the Künefe. Phyllo dough with sweet cheese, pistachio nuts, and syrup, served with ice cream on the side.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Delayed review! My husband and I went to SF in May to celebrate my birthday and wanted to find a vegetarian-friendly spot to treat our awesome friend/host on our last vacation night. This place did not disappoint. We had a reservation and were seated quickly. The bartender came by and asked if we'd be interested in drinks. He suggested a Turkish beer (our friend had that) and we went with Anchor Steam Beer. Delicious! Appetizers:Sigara böregi- fillo dough stuffed with potatoes and feta cheeseFalafel on a bed of hummusMercimek Çorbasi-lentil soupEntrees:Karides Tava: ShrimpKuzu Pirzola: Lamb chops marinated for 3 daysDesserts: KünefeBaklavaPyramid Noisette ChocolateEverything was absolutely amazing. No complaints at all. Everything we ordered was gone and we even licked our fingers. The service was great! The server, bartender, and even the owner of the restaurant came by to check on us. The owner was really nice and conversed with us for about 5/10 minutes. She was encouraging us to visit Turkey and experience the culture and food there for ourselves (it was our first time trying Turkish cuisine)! We couldn't have had a better meal to end our vacation. Thanks Tuba! We will come back to SF just to eat here again!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: [Speaking as a Turkish person who has lived in the Bay Area for the past 6 years] Hands down, the best Turkish restaurant in San Francisco, and possibly in the Bay Area as well. I wanted to change the number of people on my reservation a couple of hours prior to the time, and they were very accommodating. Though a bit on the pricier side, the food was really delicious and filling. We had the awesome meze platter as a group and destroyed it pretty quickly. As for the entrees, I had hunkarbegendi, and couldn't help myself but munch on my friends' platters of karniyarik, beyti kebap, and fish. The service was great, the waitresses/waiters were very friendly, and we even got the chance to speak to the amiable owner who showed us great hospitality. Overall, a great experience which set the tone for the rest of our evening, too. Thanks Tuba!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: We chose this restaurant as a result of a good recommendation from Yelp. It was a hassle to drive around San Francisco and find parking. It was worth it to have dinner at such a delightful venue. We walked into the restaurant. It had a warm and an intimate feeling. People were dressed in casual attire and very relaxed. It felt like being invited to the home of a dear Turkish friend for a Sunday dinner. We were seated quickly. All of the staff in the dining area appeared to be genuinely Turkish people.We ordered wine from Turkey and surrounding countries. Elena had Pinot Noir and I had Pinot Grigio. Both glasses were excellent. I ordered a prawn dish as an appetizer. It was gourmet and top 1%. I was dazzled. Elena had lentil soup. She liked it and she is an expert on lentil soups. For the main course I had meat patties.They were superb. There was so much food that I couldn't eat it all. Elena had a vegetarian dish and took some of it home to reheat for lunch today at work. The bill came in at $100. This is not expensive for a San Francisco restaurant. We also saw some criticism of service. They stay full and busy so sometimes things take a little longer. It's worth the wait. This is a special and a class venue. We will be back.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I looked forward to this place as it's been recommended and I've tried to walk in twice without a reservation (they were too busy). This time we thought ahead and brought a friend. Tuba has a $5 off check-in offer, but the waitress forgot to include it in the bill after she had me mark it as used. Maybe a free appetizer or drink would have been easier to remember?We ordered an appetizer, but bread with herb butter and feta also came, which negated the appetizer. And at $12 for two meatballs (essentially) it felt overpriced. The entrees were large (dumplings and kalides tava- sautéed shrimp with rice and veggies) so we were stuffed. Yet we still shared the signature dessert. This probably isn't what the restaurant was going for, but it reminded me of a frosted mini-wheat as a dessert...if it were larger, baked and stuffed with honey. Don't get me wrong though, it was delicious!After the entrees came it felt like we got less and less attention-- still the minimum, but forgetful (like a longer wait for water and dessert, and the check-in offer not being reflected in the bill). The food was filling and flavorful, but on the pricey side compared with the service, which was good before it got crowded. Unfortunately, 'crowded' still meant several empty tables. I'm left feeling like I expected too much. I'll probably return when I have money to spare, but not on a busy night.

SentimentText: Phenomenal meal. Three in our party. We started with the cold appetizer sampler platter and it was more than enough. More notably, every item on the plate was outstanding. I particularly loved the smoked eggplant and a spread of spiced tomato-based paste with walnuts. Also delicious was the cucumber-yogurt spread and white bean salad. Gorgeous presentation as well. Kofte (4-slider-sized burgers with Turkish spices) entree came on a beautifully arranged plate with a roasted poblano pepper, roasted tomato, fragrant basmati rice and a delicious slaw. Daily special was a lamb shank dressed with a beautiful bechamel sauce. Our server explained that the lamb shank is slow-cooked for 4 hours. It was tender, moist and falling off the bone. An outstanding entree. We were too full for dessert but enjoyed Turkish coffees which were served in exquisite cups, as were complimentary bites of lovely Turkush delight candy. Staff is warm and it's obvious they enjoy sharing their culture through their fantastic food. Their pride and love shows. This meal was a highlight of our visit to SF. A memorable experience, thank you Tuba.

SentimentText: I had purchased a google offer a few months ago and was super stoked to try this place.  I've recently discovered Turkish food and absolutely love it!  Of course, I don't know what's authentic...but what I do know...is what tastes good.  Haha.I don't really have any huge complaints about tuba.  The service was good...The food was pretty alright...and the prices were decent as Tuba seems to be a higher end Turkish restaurant.  We started off with some pide...love the stuff...ate the entire plate.  I ordered a glass of Turkish white wine although I cannot remember the name of it.  The server was wonderful...she offered me a sample prior to ordering a full glass.  The wine I had was a little on the dry side and fruity...exactly how I like it!  For our entrees, I ordered the Hünkar Beendi, pureed eggplant with mozzarella cheese topped with lamb cubes.  DELISH.  Although the pureed eggplant had the texture of baby food...it was dang tasty baby food.  the lamb was perfectly seasoned and cooked.  good stuff.  Wifey ordered the Beyti Adana, wrapped in lavash bread served with tomato sauce and yogurt.  This item we have had at other restaurants...Tuba had our least favorite.  It just didn't have that wow factor...maybe it was a tad on the dry side?  In any case, we've had better elsewhere.  We had to order dessert!  We picked the Künefe, two layers of kadayf (shredded fillo dough) filled with sweet cheese, baked to perfection and served with homemade syrup and pistachio nuts.  Mmmmmmmmmmmmm....The syrup was absolutely phenomenal on the cheese...this is a must order when you come here.I'd give Tuba a 3.4...not exactly 3.5 having to round up to 4.  I don't think I'd come back again...unless there was another offer available...maybe for a glass of wine and dessert?
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Sometimes, you just need to get in the mood -- the right mood for food, that is. We had been walking all over the Mission district for nearly an hour, finding various locations either closed or not up to snuff, when we finally approached Tuba for Turkish.Always sharing everything, we first ordered the Patlican Salatasi, an eggplant purée with bell peppers and garlic. Absolutely scrumptious, and I applied it with my knife upon the bread served at our table.  Also got the Sigara Boregi, which were sets of fillo dough including potatoes and cheese, alongside a Tzatziki dipping sauce. Entree was called their Tavuk Sote, a hot herb chicken dish with plenty of olives, mozzarella cheese, tomatoes and mushrooms, served with rice. All dishes were quite satisfying, so much so that we unfortunately were full before entirely finishing!We'd eaten an appetizer earlier on from El Techo de Lolinda at a friend's birthday, but next time, we hope to come with empty stomachs and revel in even more delicious flavors here! Their garlic spices are spot on, and that corner of Guererro (also with "Company" and "The Beast and The Hare") is certainly a hidden gem.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I feel responsible to people who may choose to go to this restaurant to let them know that we had a disturbing experience there. My brother and sister-in-law were in town from the East Coast, their first visit here, and I wanted to bring them to an interesting restaurant near my house. The reviews for this restaurant are quite strong, so I felt confident booking a reservation for us for 6:30 seating on a Wednesday night. The restaurant was pretty much empty when we arrived. The woman who was our waitress was a Slender Woman with curly dyed blonde hair and a very Stern expression. She did not greet us but asked us if we were ready to order. As it happened the fourth member of our party had not yet arrived. He was 5 minutes late. But she was insistent in standing over us waiting for us to order, so I rescued the moment by suggesting that we have some drinks and order appetizer. She did not say those words; I had to tell her that we could proceed that way. No sooner did the appetizer arrive, and we began sampling it, she came up again with a Stern demeanor, an impatient facial expression --- no welcoming, no warmth---really a cold person---and asked us to order our entrees now. I asked her are you in a hurry? And she looked at me with no change of expression very cold and said no, and then continued standing over us. So we interrupted our appetizer and figured out what we wanted to eat and took care of her needs. Not ours. Not our needs at any point in this meal. We were still finishing our food, and let the busboy know that we were not ready to have him clear. But he went ahead and started anyway. And I looked at him and said no! I had to raise my voice to get him to understand that we weren't finished, we still wanted to have our plates. So this was terrible really. I've never had such an aggravating embarrassing and really kind of humiliating experience in a restaurant before. It was made worse by the fact that I was trying to show my guests a good time, and we had the opposite of a good time.  Everybody agreed it was terrible, deliberately rude service.  The female server was by far by far the most offensive and quite calculated in doing it.   We are friendly,  polite people , and in no way deserved such cold, rude treatment.  The two stars are for good food, but it in no way compensates and I will never return to that restaurant under any circumstances that's how strongly I feel about the experience we had there. It was awful.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Having lived in Turkey for some time, I took way too long to finally try Tuba - in part because I was afraid it wouldn't live up to my high expectations about Turkish food. Well, I'm glad to say I was wrong - Tuba is fantastic. We had the meze tabagi (appetizer sampler plate), which is well worth the $25 and is a great starter for 3-4 people. Everything on it tasted authentic, from the patlican ezmesi (roasted eggplant) to the red pepper paste and the cacik (garlic-mint yogurt.) The bread was nicely toasted and came with olives and turkish cheese.It's also really in the details, like the fact that there is kekik and sumac (two common turkish spices) mixed with salt dashed on top of certain dishes and on the corners of the plates.Karniyarik (roasted eggplant stuffed with meat, tomatoes, and spices) is by far my favorite dish in turkish cuisine, and Tuba's is excellent. Hot, very savory, and very filling. They did not skimp on the portion size as I find some restaurants do with this dish.For dessert, we had the irmik helvasi, a semolina-based dish over ice cream. It was really great. If you haven't had künefe, and have room in your stomach for a slightly heavier dessert, I would try that instead / as well.The only thing that didn't quite live up to expectations was the sarma beyti kebap. While the meat was (as in the karniyarik) delicious, the tomato sauce was a little too sweet and tasted like it had a tomato paste base instead of a fresh tomato base. However, this one small thing wasn't enough to make me consider giving anything less than a 5 star review.The service was also excellent. If you know even a little turkish, be sure to try it out. The staff there is all Turkish, as are the chef and her husband who manages the space. They are very friendly and accommodating. Will definitely be returning!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Cok, cok, cok guzel!! This is the best Turkish restaurant I've ever eaten at stateside.We started with the cold mezze platter, which was so, so worth it.  The hummus, cevizli ezme, and kizartma were all to-die-for, although it was all so, so good.  The table polished off every last lettuce leaf garnish on the plate.  Phenomenal.My fiance and I are pescatarians/vegetarians so for our main entree we split the musakka and the somon.  Both were melt-in-your-mouth candidates for best meal in a restaurant.  The musakka especially was for me, truly exceptional.The restaurant surely isn't perfect; it's small, for one thing, which meant that our table wasn't ready when we arrived for our reservation at 8:00 pm on Saturday.  Still, they let us go across the street and have a beer; when the table became ready they held it for us, which mostly made up for the delay.  Mostly.Although I can resent them for putting off my life-changing experience of tasting that musakka...

SentimentText: Loved this place, a family member suggested this place and I immediately made a reservation for a date night with my boyfriend. They were very accommodating to me, as we made the reservation a couple hours before, and we were seated by the window in a cushioned area. Was not too crowded so we had ample space. We got the falafel salad which was delicious but we didn't realize that the entrees came with a very similar salad. For our entree, we ordered the lamb kabobs (AMAZING) perfectly seasoned and cooked. We also had the moussaka which had a mild flavor, covered in a gooey cheesy later, also delicious as well. For dessert, we chose the baklava which was perfect for the two of us. Then to close, we had the Turkish tea which was served in a tiny glass cup on a fancy serving tray. I was quite impressed. Would definitely recommend this place.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: i made the colossal mistake of ordering from EAT24 through tuba.  Apparently EAT24 is the worst food delivery service in american history and does not allow you to review them on Yelp (because they are owned by Yelp) or facebook (they are against facebook for some reason).  the experience was terrible with the customer service agent calling me a derogatory name.with this said, i must tell you that tuba handled it with class, professionalism and kindness.  i am very grateful for all the help Ishmeil (sorry if i spelled the name wrong) offered me, the kindness (the owner offered to drive the food) and the class of the way they handled it.i highly suggest you VISIT this place (do not order from eat24).  they are first class- their food is incredible (i have had it several times prior) and they are the kind of people that make san francisco a community.  thank you tuba for being so fabulous....keep up the great food and service.

SentimentText: So good. The flavors are totally authentic.  I'd say portions are a little small for the price, but not small in general, if that makes sense. For the money, you'd expect more food, but you won't need it. We shared a dessert and left completely stuffed. But it's San Francisco. Everything is overpriced. That's the only reason I gave 4 stars instead of 5Everything from appetizer through to dessert was delicious. Perfectly and delicately spiced. The service was impeccable, truly the friendly service the Turkish are famous for.FYI the Künefe dessert was insanely good. Go eat it. Oh and make a reservation, even on weeknights they are packed.

SentimentText: My knees go really, really weak for the Tuba Meze Tabagi...I love how it has great texture, not just mush. Hummus is super creamy, the Cevizle Esme is just divine, K Zartma is my favorite, and the Ispanak is just lovely because it is creamy without being too much. It is a bit on the expensive side: $25, but I think it's worth it for the quality and taste they produce. Will always go back for the Tuba Meze Tabagi!

SentimentText: This is a great place! The food was delicious and the wait staff all so friendly and helpful. The table bread was fresh and delicious. I tried the Sarma Beyti Kebab (Adana kebab wrapped in lavas bread, topped with homemade tomato and garlic yogurt sauce). The flavors were amazing. The lamb was just a little spicy, the tomato sauce slightly sweet with a creamy garlic sauce (is your mouth watering yet?) Another in the party tried the Somon Salmon (salmon baked and topped with spinach fume sauce, served with rice and veggies). The salmon was moist and tender in a spinach cream sauce.  So good you had to dip the delicious bread in it once the salmon was gone. And lastly Hünkar Begendi (Pureed eggplant with mozzarella cheese and garlic, topped with leg of lamb chunks in red sauce). Couldn't even tell it was eggplant. Tender chuncks of lamb. Everything was delicious.  I would also recommend their signature Künefe dessert!

SentimentText: AMAZING service, delicious food, and great location!! When my cousin said it was in the Mission, I was kind've drawn off. Busy, sketchy, hard to find parking, but it was actually 2 streets parallel to the main street. We made reservations for 5pm on a Saturday. THAT IS THE PERFECT TIME to arrive. We were seriously the first group to arrive before the dinner rush. We got the front window seat towards the street. LOVED the Adana Kebab!!!! If you love ground beef you'll love this skewered meaty dish!!! Complete your dinner with some Turkish coffee (can request for it to be sweetened*), and have it with the Kiinefe!!!!! Cheesey sweet goodness!! It looks like a fancy hashbrown, but ooooooh!! That shredded fillo dough!!! AMAZING!!!!

SentimentText: Walked by this place a few weeks ago and decided to check it out.  I went on a Thursday evening with a friend and it was about half full.  We were greeted immediately by a very friendly server.  She let us have our choice of table and took our drink order as soon as we sat down.  We decided to try the Turkish house wine which I really enjoyed.  Our server was so sweet and came by a few minutes after dropping off the glasses to make sure we liked it.  She even offered to replace it before we gave our response. The falafel salad was really good especially considering the price.  I tried some of my friend's chicken which was also delicious.  It's not the best Turkish food I've ever eaten but it's reasonably priced, the service was great, and the restaurant is very cute. Definitely a place worth checking out if you're in the mood for something different!

SentimentText: I came to Tuba for dinner with a good friend. We were seated promptly and served with water. I ordered the Köfte, which is flame-broiled beef patties. I was a little disappointed with the size of my order when it came. The meat was on the dry side, and I would take in a bite of meat with some tomatoes to give it more moisture. The patties were well-spiced and have good flavor, but it was a little too dry for me to warrant more stars.Service was decent - water was refilled when glasses were half-empty, and they were not disturbing too often asking "Is everything okay?"I would like to give this another try but I am a little hesitant because of the small portions and expensive prices.

SentimentText: I recently had dinner here for the first time with my fiance.  The restaruarant has a chic feel to it while at the same time having a family atmosphere.  The waitstaff were really attentive and our server was really knowledgebe about the menu.  She asked questions about our individual tatses and made suggestions accordingly.  Highly recommended is the Cevizli Ezme as starter, which consists of blended walnuts, Turkish red pepper paste, tomato paste, fresh garlic, olive oil,and cumin.  It has the consistency of hummus and is delicious with flat bread.  The moussaka is also not to be missed and we also enjoyed the Turkish Kavaklidere Ancrya wine we tried. It reminded me of a Sauvingon Blanc.  For dessert we had the Söbiyet, which reminded me of baklava and was delicious.

SentimentText: Usually a few months after an international trip I'll locate a restaurant here at home that serves the cuisine of the region visited and reminisce through food. Istanbul was the destination in January, and I have lovely memories of the city's abundant food. On Istanbul's Asian shore there were terrific fish markets, with typically a small cafe in back popular at lunch time where one can eat well and cheaply. This experience prompted me to select the sea bream, one of two specials offered us at the outset of a recent dinner at Tuba, not necessarily expecting a mirror recreation of what was made available in Turkey but curious nonetheless what the local chefs might make of the dish. My girlfriend ordered the karniyarik eggplant off of the menu. As the food began to arrive the server asked if we intended to share our dishes, which is certainly feasible given the ample portions delivered and perhaps is the answer to one of the few repeated complaints on Yelp (the price per entree, that is). I think the entrees are meant to be shared. If/when we return to Tuba we have decided we will order one entree and augment this with mezzes. I think this will work very well. My sea bream was tasty but I'll likely choose something different next time. Ayran appeared on the drink menu, which thrilled me because we had tried the salted yogurt drink while on holiday and liked it a lot. I had to order it at Tuba, and it tasted very similar, just as refreshing paired with the food. We had actually made a reservation for early in the evening, then canceled because we weren't ready to eat yet and ended up going later just ahead of the dinner rush. We had a pokey little table pushed against the wall near the wait station that I was prepared not to enjoy but that turned out fine. The high-backed, cushioned chairs were extremely comfortable and ticked up the enjoyment scale. There appear to be a lot of people on hand to wait on the hungry at this establishment, translating to warm and convivial attention. We got to blab about our visit to Istanbul to a young woman who wasn't even our server but that had approached us anyway. The maitre d'hotel complimented me on the scarf I was wearing, and later held the door open for us to exit. I remember a similar warmth and hospitality extended to us in Istanbul, so experiencing it here was a sort of special confirmation of something that I won't preach about on Yelp. What a nice experience, though.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Tuba is great. Stayed in the neighborhood and got takeout from here for 3 people.We all shared: the Tuba Meze Tabagi (a taste of all cold mezes), the Tavuk Sis, the Sarma Beyti Kebabi, the Sebzeli Guvec, and the Kunefe  for dessert. Perfect for 3 people to gorge on, and came out almost an even $100 - totally worth it.Need to eat here more often!

SentimentText: I am judging Tuba against the food I had while traveling in Turkey - and it meets expectations.To Start- Dolmas: and they were delicious. I hate when dolmas are served so cold you know they were just pulled from a fridge. These had a delicate texture, flavor and came at the right temperature. They were also served with a small green salad.The Bread plate: which they give everyone is really nice. I love the spreads that came with it.Lentil Soup: It seemed to me in Turkey every restaurant had just amazing amazing soup. This red lentil is a great representation of that. It had a nice amount of pepper in it that I appreciated and I felt it unnecessary to add a squeeze of lemon (which came with it). Falafel Salad: The falafels were a little to firm for my preference but they were delicious just the same. The salad was an excellently priced and healthy option your vegetarian friends and friends on diets will appreciate. Stuffed eggplant: My friend doesn't like bell peppers so she picked them out of it but she enjoyed the dish. (We went to Tuba because she was missing a Turkish friend's home cooking). Rice Pudding: I thought it would be served hot because of the description. It was served cold and was really good.Kunefe: is a sweet cheese wrapped in shredded filo dough, baked, drizzled with syrup and sprinkled with pistachios. I'd never had this dessert before but I would tell anyone going to Tuba to order it. Turkish coffee: They asked how sweet I wanted it. I told them to serve it how they would in turkey and they gave it to me "only a little sweet" because I was having it with dessert. I'd seriously go back just for this. The presentation is very cool as well.Service: very attentive and friendly without being too in your face. So as you can see the two of us had quite a sampling of the food. As soon as I got home I told my boyfriend we should go and we probably will in a few weeks. Go!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: It is always reassuring to  find that there are  things that can be relied upon!  First, I  have always been well-advised by reviews from Yelpers. When so many people say it is good, it always is.  Second, the food and service at Tuba was excellent.  I will most definitely return to try other things on the menu.  And third, we had a lovely evening with our friends.  Who can ask for more? It is so nice that the tempting  descriptions of the dishes on the menu are actually followed by really delicious food!  I had the smoky eggplant purée topped with chunks of leg of lamb in red sauce..sooo good.  The others had the succulent lamb chops and the baked eggplant stuffed with ground beef and veggies.  We shared the scrumptious Tuba salad, and Noah's Pudding to round off a great meal.  I was very happy that we tried this place and can't wait to come bak!

SentimentText: We came here because of Groupon. My fault for going on the expiry date, so we waited for almost an hour for a table (with reservation). I can't comment much about the service, since it's not really fair to judge the poor service because of the massive Groupon crowds. They comped us and the owner apologized and came to our table several times. That's a nice touch.Hummus is super delicious. I was 70% full eating it with the bread that they gave before my entree came. Falafel is yummy, I like the simple version without the goat cheese inside. For entree, the chicken kebab is very tender and juicy. The rice is just ok, which is kind of a bummer. The sauteed chicken is also really good, it's like chicken and tomato stew.We ordered 4 different desserts and I think the Pyramid Noisette Chocolate and Künefe are sooo good. Künefe is like a sweet grilled cheese sandwich (but instead of bread, they use phyllo dough), very yummy. Helvas and Sütlaç are kinda weird and have these soft rice texture. Not my favorite.We ended up leaving the Mission early because of the food coma. Very satisfying dinner. 4 stars!

SentimentText: This place will leave you wanting to come back again and again. The atmosphere is warm and inviting make sre to make a reservation tho it can get full. I was new to Turkish food and a vegetarian and worried what they might have to offer with no meat. They had plenty of choices for me and oh everything was just amazing! They have so many small plates or mazes as they call them that you could share and make a meal of them. Or order a few small dishes and entrees as our group did and share family style. I highly recommend the larger of the small plates to share called Tuba Meze which consists of all their cold dips, hummus, and spreads. The red pepper Walnut spread is a knockout. Also their hit Meze plate called Sigara Böregi... Fillo dough stuffed with potatoes, feta cheese, parsley. This cannot be missed. We were a large group so we got to try a alot nothing disappointed, same goes with the carnivores in my party they enjoyed many of the lamb dishes and seafood. The bread is house made and the waiters are super attentive and helpful. You'll feel right at home. Make sure to try some Turkish wine or beer!

SentimentText: How to Woo your Honey "Flight of the Conchords" style: 1) Tell her: "Looking at the room, I can tell that you are the most beautiful girl in the ... room.  In the whole wide room." "And when you're on the street, depending on the street, I bet you are definitely in the top 3 good looking girls on the street." 2) Buy her a kebab. She'll be impressed by the selection of kebabs at Tuba.  Chicken, Lamb, Shrimp, etc.  If she's feeling indecisive, she can get the mixed grill. I ordered the Shrimp Kebabs and they were awesome ($17). Two sizeable grilled skewers of large shrimp with little wedges of lemon in between. The cool, creamy cucumber yogurt that came with it was a great accompaniment as were the perfectly cooked julienned veggies, roasted tomato, and rice pilaf that rounded out the plate. Hummus fans will enjoy Tuba's version as it is smooth and garlicky ($6).  Lentil Soup lovers will adore Tuba's pureed and flavorful tomato-y version. ($5) She will enjoy the sexy ambiance.  Deep red walls, brightly colored geometric art, elegant embroidered pillows, dark wood furniture, a cozy bar in the back, and warm and friendly service up front will help you seal the deal. 3) And don't forget to say: "I can't believe, I'm sharing a kebab.  With the most beautiful girl I have ever seen with a kebab." "Cause you're so beautiful.  Like a tree. Or a high class prostitute.  You're so beautiful.  You could be a part time model.  (But you'd probably still have to keep your normal job.)" (If this doesn't work, then she's not a FOTC fan and should you really be dating her?) youtube.com/watch?v=89zO…

SentimentText: My experience is that SF is kinda hit-and-miss when it comes to authentic foods from anywhere other than near-Asia (Cantonese, Sushi, etc. usually are fine), and Meso-American food in the Mission. There are a few stand-outs like Kokkari for Greek food, but other than that I've been left wanting.Authenticity is the first word that comes to mind when I think about Tuba. While there are certainly a number of blanket "Mediterranean" dishes on the menu, there are other things that I'm not sure you could find elsewhere -- the Kofte Kebab is not the kind you might get at a Pakistani place -- not mild, but complex in flavor and not overpowering. Their lamb was expertly cooked -- not tough, not too gamey -- and we were very pleased away by the solid wine list including a good number of imports and locals.I think the portion sizes were more than adequate -- my partner and I both walked away feeling full and satisfied. That said, the shrimp dish we got was a little overdone, and it did feel like something they just grabbed from Greece or Eastern Italy.Our service was quick and attentive, but no-nonsense either, which is fine by me, but a turn-off to some. That said, the menu (with the exception of the desserts which were mostly philo-based)  is *extremely* gluten-free friendly, which is wonderful for me... I really didn't have to ask many questions about what is in what like I do at other restaurants. Making me feel welcome and not like an inconvenience to the chefs? That's what earned Tuba its fifth star.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: As a SF Destination Manager and Personal Concierge it is my job and duty to find THE best restaurants for my clients and I did!Tube provides unbelievable service,the staff was incredibly warm and the flavors in everything we tasted were out of this world!!From the cold "meze" of hummus to the Cevizli Ezme (Walnuts, Turkish red pepper paste, tomato paste, fresh garlic, olive oil, and cumin) with their fresh baked bread to hot " meze" the Peynirli Karides (Prawns sautéed with tomatoes and garlic in a lovely spicy pepperoncini sauce and topped with feta cheese) and pan-fried Içli Köfte (Bulgur on the outside and the inside stuffed with spicy ground beef with crushed walnuts & garlic) to the SPECTACULAR Turkish Moussaka and the scrumptious Tavuk Sote Herb (chicken that is BEYOND juicy, perfectly cooked in tomato sauce, green olives, onions, peppers topped with mozzarella cheese with rice and salad) And dessert? Forget about it!! I couldn't eat another bite but oh my!! Chef Merram is a wonderful GIANT talented GENIUS in the kitchen!!

SentimentText: The food here is DELICIOUS!  It brought me back to when I visited Turkey a couple of months back and boy was it reminiscent of the tasty Turkish food I had!  This is what I sampled:-Turk Salatasi (Turkish Salad):  recommended by our server as an appetizer, this salad is simple yet tasty and HEALTHY!  So good- we devoured it quickly!-Karniyarik:  one of their signature dishes made with one of my favorite ingredients- eggplant!  It consists of eggplant stuffed with ground beef, tomatoes, onions, and parsley.  This entree was very flavorful.  If you've never tasted Turkish food before, I recommend trying this!  Oh it's sooooo good.My entire group enjoyed their dishes as well.  The atmosphere is warm and cozy, and the servers are friendly.  We dropped in without reservations and luckily they had one table available.  It seems like a popular place so I recommend making reservations ahead of time.  I'll definitely be back!

SentimentText: Yesterday we came across Tuba walking randomly around the neighbourhood, being rather hungry I suggested we take a quick look. I have already heared of Tuba, but wasn't sure it was worth the trip, eating Turkish food outside the Middle East is hardly ever a mind blowing experience! Upon a closer look, we quickly realised this wasn't your average kebab spot. It was beautiful and effortlessly exotic. I was looking quite shabby minus chic having been out all day backpack, tights and trainers. The lady at the door caught us as we were about to walk away, she said I look fine sit down and enjoy your time. Everyone was dressed up nicely though, just so you would know! They are mainly indoors but they have about 3-4 tables sitting 2-4 people outside on the street. The street itself is quite and suburby looking so it was very pleasent. The food is incredible!!!! They seem to use different spices and herbs, so don't expect it to taste familiar. We ordered: Hummus for starters (delicious) comes with their complimentary bread ( also white cheese crumbles, olives and a butter spread).Adena kebab, a large minced meat skewer (spicy) sereved with rice (I would come back for the rice alone) and salad. Eggplants and  mozzarella mash topped with a red beef stew (Amazing). Finally Kunefe and tea. We had no room for this at all but it had to be done judging by how great the meal was. My +1 the kunefe expert says it is one of the top in the world. Too sweet for some but the tea cuts through it well if unsweetened. You could maybe ask for the syrup on the side too. The kunefe comes with mildly chewy vanilla ice cream. I am declaring my love for this place right now! A beautiful place, brilliant ( and I don't say this often) warm service and just great food that makes you really happy.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: We got a craving for Turkish food after spending a few hours at Mission Cliffs nearby and found Tuba on yelp. It was new year's eve and their schedule was pretty full with reservations, but they were kind enough to fit us in right before the evening rush. Excited to come back here and try the rest of the menu another time.

SentimentText: My friends and I ate dinner here on Saturday night. The restaurant was not too busy, considering we were eating around 9:30pm.   The service was good and the servers friendly. We ordered the tuba cold platter, which came with all the cold appetizers.   The ones that I enjoyed were the grilled eggplant puree (Pathcan salatasi grilled), Piyaz (white bean salad), and Ezme (a tomato paste with walnuts).  My entree was the mixed grill. Served with chicken and lamb shish, kotfe, adana, and lamb chop, it was a lot of meat.  I substituted my rice for more sautéed vegetables, which was a good choice.  It allowed me to eat more meat than starchy carbs. I still was not able to finish my meal and took the rest home.  A good option to go to in the Mission if you want something different. Or if you don't want to drive to the Tenderloin.

SentimentText: When my daughter's super cool 1st grade teacher told her that his favorite restaurant of the moment was Tuba I had to check it out.  I had never had Turkish food, so it was  intriguing on that front as well.  We were a group of five, at various life stages (single, new mom, older mom w/ older kids, etc.) so we always get that early bird table-this time 5:15.   There were only two tables until 6pm, so service was super attentive, but judging the staff it seemed like it would be like that anyway. Food was so tasty, actually using spices and herbs rather than dumping it with too much salt.  None of it was spicy, just super flavorful.  We did the app that let you try all the cold appetizers, and shared all the dinners-keftka, kebabs (lamb and chicken), dumplings that looked like someone pinched them with the tiniest fingers ever, and  salmon w/ yogurt sauce, And for dessert it would've been easier to tell them which ones we didn't want since we ended up ordering all but two items.  Rice pudding and their house specialty (listed as such-name escapes me) were table favs.  So nice to try something outside of our normal routine of sushi, Italian, and burgers and pizza (thanks to kids!). Highly recommended!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Authentic Turkish Cuisine is served here in an elegant ambiance. Ezme, Manti and irmik helvasi dessert are traditional fare that many places don't offer and those three things were some of the most memorable and tasty eats I had while visiting Turkey. I know everyone thinks kabobs when they think Turkish food but there is so much more to the cuisine than meat on a stick. The Ezme was something I had from a street vendor in Istanbul. This was the cart that the locals lined up for. The Ezme paste of crushed walnuts, tomatoes and spices were slathered in a lavash style piece of bread and then whole leaves of romaine lettuce were placed on top and rolled up to be easy to eat as you roamed around the city. At Tuba they present it a bit more elegantly with the paste prettily plopped on a plate and the bread broken into pita chip like pieces to scoop it up with. The Manti is similar to beef ravioli but the sauce that tops it is a yogurt/tomato sauce. This is good stuff. The creamy , tangy yogurt sauce is incredibly addicting. It's also pretty to look at with the contrast of white and red swirled together and not completely mixed. The irmik helvasi is a semolina flour desert that I stopped a passing boy in the Grand Bazaar to try. In Turkey, the ice cream was encased in the flour mixture but here it's served on the side. The slightly gritty texture of the moist semolina tastes heavenly with the cold smooth accompaniment of ice cream. Tuba restaurant is a great find for authentic Turkish delights here in the states. Now if they served Salep(a warm horchata like drink made from the tubers of an orchid), and Dondurma(sticky ice cream) I'd be in Turkish foodie heaven but alas, the special orchid flour that is the main ingredients of those two things are a rarity outside of Turkey.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Tuba is NOT a vegetarian restaurant, and I do not understand why it is categorized as such on Yelp. The vast majority of the menu is heavy on the meat factor (I mean, it specializes in kebabs...). I came with a vegetarian friend and we were able to comfortably order non-meat items, but this is by no means a vegetarian specialty restaurant.This confusion thankfully did not mar our otherwise tasty meal. I haven't had too much experience with Turkish food in the past, so this was a great introductory course. We got the Mucver ($7) and Musakka ($16) to share, which filled us up pretty fast. Mucver is a zucchini pancake with a refreshing yogurt sauce. I love yogurt as a sauce/condiment! Musakka is a dish of something that resembles lasagna in looks. The flavors were rich, yet not food coma-inducing. For some unknown reason, I actually really enjoyed the rice on the side.The place started filling up substantially after 7PM on a Wednesday night. The space is relatively small and the lighting is dark. The prices might look a bit daunting at first, but I do think they are justified by the portion sizes and quality!
Label: Genuine
