SentimentText: The best Turkish restaurant in the San Francisco Bay area! My son and his wife honeymooned in Turkey and Tubas seemed appropriate to begin their anniversary celebration. The four of us have worked and lived in Europe, and have experienced great ethnic restaurants. Accordingly, our expectations were high. The dolmas were superior... Better than any we had along the Bosphorus. The lamb chops were also outstanding. The Adana Kebab were great - almost as good as my lamb chops. This is authentic Turkish cuisine and well done. The cost was quite reasonable by San Francisco standards. Service was gracious, fast and attentive; the ambiance is informal and inviting; the selection was broad and varied, to include the usual Turkish drinks plus Turkish beers and wines - a wonderful place for an intimate evening with friends and family. Well worth the drive into the city!

SentimentText: Turkish deliciousness!I seriously love that Tuba moved into the neighborhood a few years ago. We eat in occasionally, and get take out all the time.The hot & cold appetizers are great, particularly the goat-cheese stuffed falafel salad, the Mercimek Çorbasi, crab cakes, Patlican Salatasi, and Cevizli Ezme.For mains, we're addicted to the Tavuk Sote (chicken in tomato sauce with veggies), Hünkar Begendi (lamb cubes on cheesy pureed eggplant in amazing red sauce), and Musakka.Dishes are large, and just super tasty. If you're eating in, the Efes Turkish pilsner is excellent.We love Tuba, and are very happy to see it continuing to do good business!

SentimentText: This place can get crazy busy.. I repeat - CUH-RAY-ZEE busy.  Fortunately, the food is worth it.  Made a 9:00 reservation on a Thursday night.  Drove through the neighborhood and zoomed right past it.  I had enough time to squeal out, 'There it is!' before we hit the end of the block. Hubby dropped me off, as we were running a tad bit late. Successfully securing our table, I perused the menu and knew we were gonna have to make some tough decisions.  We settled on: * The Hot Platter - the sampler platter of their hot appetizers. Loved the falafels and deep fried cheese (who wouldn't?!) * Hünkar Beendi, which is pureed eggplant with mozzarella cheese topped with lamb cubes. You'd never know it was eggplant; the texture was silky smooth.  Paired wonderfully with the tender lamb cubes.  Mmm.. I almost couldn't share it.. * Chicken dish that had tomato sauce and onions & peppers.  * Künefe - One of my absolute favorite desserts.  We order it at almost every Greek festival we go to.  It's layers of shredded fillo dough filled with sweet cheese, baked to perfection and served with homemade syrup and pistachio nuts. I am seriously drooling right now.. * Turkish Coffee - When in Rome - erm, Turkey, right? Definitely some good ish right there. Bold flavors and strong enough to get you home and then some. ;)
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: We've been here a few times, most recently to celebrate a friend's birthday, and Tuba was perfect - nice atmosphere, excellent food at fair prices, and very attentive service. We couldn't have asked for more.  The cold meza plate was amazing as always, I really liked my eggplant stuffed with ground beef, and my husband devoured his prawns in pepperoncini sauce - we'd come back for that dish alone.  Can't wait for an excuse to go back!

SentimentText: Great food and decently priced for the portions. I'm giving them a four because I want to come back and try more to make sure everything is as good as it was last night. Sautéed shrimp with asparagus - perfectly seasoned and great flavorsLamb shank special - meat fell off the bone, but the gravy seemed a bit bland compared to the other flavors.Stuffed eggplant - not as exciting for me since I don't eat beef much, but well prepared and great flavorKünefe. Hands down. Best part of the meal.

SentimentText: First off, I have to say that parking in this part of the city was a total disaster. I think we drove about 5 blocks out in every direction before finally having to park by Dolores Park, but I digress - this is a review about a restaurant not about walking 6 blocks in stilettos (lesson learned). The restaurant was interesting for lack of a better word. We came for a friends birthday party and I had no idea what type of food we were getting. The place is small and long. It's unfortunately really loud too, even without a ton of people in it. The ordered the Shepherd salad, which wasn't at all what I was expecting. I was expecting some lettuce with my veggies, but I misunderstood the concept of a Greek salad I guess. It was pretty good but I had cucumber burps for a few hours afterwards. My boyfriend ordered the Kofte kebab which was really delicious. Charred in the grill, yum!We unfortunately didn't get to try anything else, I would have loved to have to baklava since that is my favorite but no such luck. Im not a huge fan of Greek food so I don't know if id be back but I would recommend it at least.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Well here goes my very first experience with Turkish cuisine! On a Tuesday night, Mr. MC decided to take me out on a date night. Not telling me where we were going, I had no idea what sort of food we were getting...but hey! Tuba was definitely a pleasant experience!He made reservations at 6pm. We arrived late due to traffic and walked in at 6:15pm. Parking wasn't bad, but you definitely have to look.The restaurant only had 2 other tables when we sat down. This place is very quaint. Dim lightening, colorful decor, and a special scent within the restaurant. It was relaxing, yet very classy. We were than greeted by a waitress that handed us the menu and poured us glasses of water. Being the very first time of having Turkish cuisine for both of us...we needed some time to digest the menu. Momentarily, this gentlemen came over and asked if it was our first time. We later on figured out his name was Burke. He gave us recommendations and was very personable. As my boyfriend butcher the names of the dishes, Burke was so nice to tell us that it is pronounced the way it looks. We decided to go with:Appetizer: Cevizli Ezme Walnuts, Turkish red pepper paste, and tomato paste with fresh garlic, olive oil, and cumin. SO GOOD! The bread was fresh and delicious. The red pepper paste really caught Mr.MC's attention. It complimented the bread very well. It was tasty.For entrees, we went ahead and ordered two to share:Sarma Beyti Kebabi -  Adana kebab wrapped in lavas bread, topped with homemadetomato and garlic yogurt sauce. VERY saucy. If you are not someone that likes too much sauce, you might not like this dish. However, this dish was very flavorful. The garlic yogurt sauce was just right. It wasn't sour or anything. It was a generous portion.Manti - Dumplings stuffed with ground beef, topped with garlic yogurt sauce,pepper flakes and dried mint. The dumpling were tiny! They were bite-sized! But the meat within was very fresh. The ground beef was a tad bit dry, however, it didn't both us because it paired well with the the sauce as well. Bread and water were refilled without request. We were able to eat the bread with the yogurt sauce as well!At the end, we were stuffed but we HAD to order Pyramid Noisette Chocolate to satisfy my sweet cravings and 2 orders of the Turkish coffee. I am a coffee lover and I approve! Turns out Turkish coffee isn't in a cup or glass, it actually comes in a super tiny small mug shot. Very strong.Burke was very helpful and personable throughout our whole dining experience. He definitely made our first Turkish cuisine an awesome one! Thank you!p.s. check in on yelp for $5 off!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Tuba is a great go-to place for a night out with friends, or just a casual dinner for two.  The food is delicious, the service is attentive, the ambiance is comfortable, and it's totally reasonable.  Kind of awesome across the board.  I came here with 4 girlfriends and we all loved it.  While they offer both meat and non-meat dishes, vegetarians, gluten-free folks, and vegans would also love this place.

SentimentText: Another monthly dinner with my cousin and another great pick on his part. We started off with the dolma. Having had them before, I knew what I was in for . . . he on the other hand didn't know what it was and didn't care for it. It's ok, more for me!I had the Adana Kabab. I'm not a fan of lamb at all, but had to give this a try. The spices mixed in with the sirloin and lamb was fantastic. I could have had eaten another plate of this. For dessert we tried the Kunefe. I don't like cheese, but you would have never know it was cheese. It oddly had the taste of french toast. This is a must try for sure!

SentimentText: Great neighborhood restaurant with friendly yet effective service.Have come here on multiple occasions on busy nights without a reservation and was politely and promptly accommodated. Some restaurants in this area can be downright rude towards walk-ins, so the service was much appreciated.Everything I've had here has been excellent, from the appetizer platter to the moussaka, but if I had to pick a standout it would probably be the kunefe dessert. It's delightfully chewy yet flaky and served hot with a cold scoop of ice cream on top.Service here has always been great as well. The owner will even occasionally come out and chat with customers!

SentimentText: I will never try to make hummus again.  Mine tastes like mud compared to theirs- holy cow, it was so delish I could have taken the whole tray and just had that with bread for dinner.Wasn't a fan of their crushed walnuts dish; ezme but if you love nuts and tomatoe paste, you may be more keen to it than myself.  Enjoyed the refreshing shepard salad with abundant cucumber and the icli kofte had a wonderful thick and crispy bulgar shell encasing a spicy ground sirloin.  That was much smaller than I expected, as the icli kofte was basically two small oval, the length of an index finer and a couple fingers thick.  The salad on the other hand was much bigger and probably would have been too much for just two people if they didn't cucumber.  Their kabab was delicious and had so much flavor.  Also big portion!  Ours was a bit dry but I think it's because we took so long eating everything else they had to keep it waiting for us.  Pyramid Noisette Chocolate with hazelnut mousse and chocolate mousse sounds like something I would love, but it fell short.  It didn't taste like it was made with quality and care as I would have wanted it to.  On the other hand, the baklava was perfect!! My recommendation for two on a date: hummus, icli kofte, a kabab and baklava. enjoy!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: After visiting Istanbul I've come to appreciate Turkish food, and aside from what you would get in the motherland Tuba is the next best thing. In my opinion it's the best Turkish restaurant in the Bay Area.On my last visit we had the icli kofte appetizer which is ground beef mixed with walnuts, rolled into a ball, covered in breading, fried, then served on a bed of yogurt. How can you go wrong. Other menu standouts I've tried include beyti kebap (kebap wrapped in lavash bread and topped with tomato and yogurt sauce), manti (meat dumplings served in yogurt sauce--I guess I really like my dairy) and Adana kebap. The Adana kebap is different then those I've had elsewhere (and from what I'm told more authentic). The meat had a softer texture and was a lot spicier, so keep that in mind. I find most Turkish food pretty heavy so by the time I'm done with an entree I feel like I'm going to die and therefore too full for dessert. If you don't have that problem I'd suggest the kunefe and or irmik helvasi.They have a nice selection of Turkish beers (gotta love Efes Dark) and wines. I had the red Kavaklidere which was like a pinot noir and very good.Service is friendly, but that may be because I always come with native Turkish speakers. Our last waiter was a real chatty Cathy but not in a creepy or oppressive way. I'll probably come back here before I go back to Turkey again, which is ok with me. Afiyet olsun!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Came here with some coworkers last Friday and had a great dinner. The food was tasty, but the place was a bit squished with the backs of chairs touching each out making it kind of uncomfortable. We ordered the following items:- Falafel on hummus - very good- Kofte - DELICIOUS, high recommend it!- Dumplings - very good, I've tried Turkish dumplings at other places and didn't enjoy it that much, but this place nailed the combo of tart and meatyWe also had a bottle of Turkish wine which was good, but nothing amazing.Overall, this is a great spot in the Mission close to some cool spots. I would definitely recommend coming here for dinner!

SentimentText: Came here on a Saturday night for a simple birthday dinner. I'm pretty sure you have to make a reservation to eat here because the place was packed at all times. We ordered the Dolma and the Tuba Hot platter. The dolma consisted of rice wrapped in grape leaves, and the tuba hot platter contained crab cakes, falafel, sirloin wrapped in some sort of shell, pan fried zucchini, and pan fried cheese. I surprisingly enjoyed the pan fried zucchini the most.I ordered the Adana Kebab (spicy sirloin and lamb) which turned out to be amazing. I loved dipping the meat in the yogurt and eating it with the rice. The rice was absolutely DELICIOUS. I wish I could have more of it! I tried a little of the lamb chops from the Mixed Grill which was also very good. I wish you could order an extra serving of rice!Because we were celebrating a birthday, they gave us a complimentary dessert, which I believe is the Pyramid noisette chocolate. The only downside about the restaurant was the Chocolate cup creme brulee. We ordered three of them-- two of them were frozen on the inside, and one was soft and melting. We assumed there was something wrong with the melting creme brulee and complained to the waitress. The waitress said that the dessert was supposed to be like that, which meant two out of three of the creme brulees were prepared incorrectly. Other than that, everything here was delicious and I'm definitely coming back here for more!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Wow- real Turkish food in the City! This place is fantastic!Went here last night for our monthly Anniversary dinner having read about it from Patricia Untermann and all I can say is how right she was in her review.Nice room at the corner of 22nd + Guerrero, well decorated but not fussy. The menu is wonderful, with lists of cold and hot appetizers and entrees and kababs and more, we ordered both the cold and hot mezes and were knocked out. How good were they? I could have sworn I was back in Istanbul, the flavors were so perfectly balanced and presented. Everything we ate, and between the 2 of us we can pack it in and we did, was superb. Service was welcoming and friendly and helpful, wine and beer list offered wines I'd never heard of and will be back to try. Come and see for yourself, you won't be disappointed. Enjoy!

SentimentText: Unfortunately, I do not agree with the rest of the Yelp community regarding this restaurant. The service and the food was nothing special and I will not be coming back. Let's start with the service. As soon as my friend and I entered, we got a bad taste in our mouth. I made open table reservations for 5 people and at the last minute, another friend of mine decided to join. I forgot to update the open table reservation, but didn't think it would have been that big of a deal. When I mentioned that there will be one more person joining us, the man who greeted us did not look happy. He was snappy with me and told me that they have a table for 5 already set up with us but he "guesses" that he can sit us at a larger table. Sorry, I didn't realize adding an additional person was going to be that big of a deal... I'll go on --- when our waitress asked my friend if he would like a recommendation of their Turkish wine, she recommended the most expensive glass of wine on the list. It's not as though my friend had a problem paying for it, it was more principle and a bit shady. Our water glasses were never refilled unless we asked. Also, I noticed that the same man that greeted us, rolled his eyes at one point when he walked by our table for no reason at all. I understand that our party may have been louder than the rest of the parties (we like to laugh and talk and not just stuff our mouths - sorry), but we do not deserve to have somebody who works there roll their eyes at us. In fact, I believe that man is either the owner or the Manager. As for food... nothing special. Their hummus was probably the only decent item from everything else we had ordered. The only annoying thing that happened (and never happens at other restaurants) is that my friend has an allergy for gluten and asked for cucumbers instead of their bread for the hummus. Although they were able to accommodate her, they charged her extra for 8 slices of cucumbers. Again, it's not about the money, it's the principle. For my main dish, I had their shrimp. The shrimp tasted extremely bland and they had no Turkish feel to them whatsoever. It came with plain rice and some veggies. I could have made it at home and saved my money. The rest of my party were also not thrilled with the food. All in all, I don't recommend this place. I hope the owners and management read this review and make a few changes.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Went here for dinner with a friend - Pros:* Great ambiance* Friendly server* LOTS of veggie options! We ordered an appetizer platter which allowed us to sample almost all of their vegetarian starters. It was a lot of food, but a great way to try a lot of new things*Focaccia bread was amazing (warm and perfect to eat with the appetizer platter)Cons:* Sigara Böregi (Fillo dough with potato and feta) entree was very bland and looked like a thin spring roll - whole dish was just oily and lacking any distinct flavor.* Though we sampled a lot of dishes in the appetizer platter (Tuba Meze Tabagi), only the Cevizli Ezme, Haydari and the Kizartma stuck out as unique and were really yummy. The others (esp Humus and Dolma) seemed like substandard versions of dishes I could've eaten at any other Mediterranean restaurant.Overall, it was an ordinary dining experience and I probably wouldn't come back.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: My nephew took me here last night because he lived 5 years in Turkey. We got there early and we got a table right away, the one another review noted as the table by the wait station. It was not a problem and in fact Iiked it because when the place starting filling up, we had no noise issues. My nephew thought the food was very authentic and we both were very happy with what we ordered. I ordered mezzas that we shared and he had a kebob entree which was declared as spicy on the menu and it was not. I only had a taste which I liked a lot, ANY spice is too spicy for me but this didn't bother me.We had the dessert with shredded filo, cheese, honey and ice cream it was delicious. IF you like cheese, this is a must. I also had the Turkish beer, Efes Pilsner. Which I found refreshing.Service was perfect with one exception. Which is why I gave it 4 stars. I was thirsty and they brought warm water in a hot glass. I asked for ice water and they put a few in that melted immediately. I feel they should have paid attention and offered more ice or brought a fresh glass with ice in it. That would have been great service.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Tuba's relaxed, unpretentious atmosphere and good food make it a nice dinner spot. I was torn between ordering the lamb chops and lamb kabob and ultimately decided on the latter.  While my lamb was very good, my friend's chicken kabob was average (not bad, just nothing to tear your pants off over), as was my wife's Hünkar Begendi (eggplant smothered with mozzarella). For desert, I had the Künefe, fillo dough stuffed with sweet cheese and topped with syrup, which was also pretty good. Overall I enjoyed my visit and there's definitely lots of appetizing things on the menu that are worth a try.  Maybe not a destination restaurant I'd return to over and over again, but if you plan to be in the Mission for dinner, it's worth a visit.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Looking for a place with nice ambiance, good food and great service? Tuba is the place to be.This is a nice catch up with your friends place and also good for dates. I advise making a reservation, this place place is cozy.We started with the Sigara Borei appetizer ~ pan fried feta cheese pastries with yogurt dill dipping sauce. It reminded me of lumpia with feta. It was served piping hot & crispy, really good. Entrees ~I had the Stuffed Eggplant with pine nuts, onions, tomatoes, feta and rice. A flavorful, light dish, I enjoyed it very much. I normally don't eat much rice since it takes up valuable real estate in my belly, but the rice with this dish is irresistible. Try it.My friend had the Köfte Kebab ~ ground beef and lamb with fresh herbs. I had a bite of the kebab and it was packed full of delicious flavor. The service was very friendly and helpful. We had a great time at Tuba. I highly recommend dining here.

SentimentText: I am not an expert on Turkish food, but we have enjoyed our two dinners here quite a bit. The service is friendly, helpful, and prompt without being rushed. The the food is delicious, the portions ample. For appetizers, we've tried a white bean salad, a fried zucchini dish with yogurt sauce, and the falafel salutasi (falafel stuffed with goat cheese, served over a bed fresh greens with an orange-y vinaigrette). All for these were delicious. The moussaka, karniyarik (stuffed eggplant), and manti (small meat-stuffed dumplings with yogurt sauce and spices) were all delicious! There's a wine list with a variety of Turkish, European, and California wines, but we found we got something better when we asked what they had that was NOT on the list. This place is definitely worth a try if you already like, or would like to try, Turkish food.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: My experience at Tuba was excellent.My parents were in town and had requested Mediterranean food, so I picked this spot - good reviews and in a cute location. I was pleasantly surprised that, instead of being a zoo like some Mission restaurants, it was quiet and mellow. It felt like we had found a fantastic secret!Great food! All things you'd expect from a Mediterranean spot - there were these zucchini fritter items that were positively divine, and the flatbread that came before our meal was irresistible! We took our server's advice and tried a Turkish wine. It was quite good - maybe not what I want every day but a really nice pairing for the food. Nice to try something new. I had lamb on a bed of eggplant melted with mozzarella (don't ask me the official name). The eggplant shocked me - it was so unctuous and creamy. My Mom's dish also used eggplant as a base. I honestly have never seen the ingredient used so artfully before. Well priced for quality food in SF. The service was superb. Everyone who helped us was kind and, always a good sign, actually Turkish. The owner started chatting with my Dad and told us he and his wife had recently taken over the restaurant, maybe 2 months ago, although they had helped found it and have been involved since it opened. He told me she knew over 25 different eggplant dishes! They're working on creating a more seasonal, rotating menu. I'm looking forward to seeing what they have in store!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Thanks to Groupon I now know about this lovely Turkish restaurant. I've been a happy vegan at other Turkish restaurants, especially in NY, so I'm thrilled to find a good local one.I ordered the lentil soup, dolmas, and hummus. My partner ordered the stuffed falafel. The Turkish bread is wonderful -- kind of like really good focaccia but better. Softer.The lentil soup looked different than I expected -- thicker. The taste was quite nice except it had a kick to it. I'm a bit sensitive to hotter spices (peppers) so my partner finished it and loved it.The dolmas were superb -- more olive oil then the tangy lemon or whatever is used in other dolmas. There were a few pine nuts and maybe cornichons...they were simply delicious, okay?Now...I am a hummus connoisseur. I ate hummus multiple times every day I was in Israel and there are subtleties involved. This hummus was creamy, tasty, and definitely lacked that heavy lemony taste that many hummuses (and just what the hell is the plural for hummus?) -- for me -- ruin the experience.By the way, my partner loved the falafel -- stuffed with cheese -- as it was nice and moist. So often falafel is dry. I didn't try them 'cause I'm the happy vegan, remember?
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I came upon this restaurant when searching for a good place for a group in the Mission.  Our friend was visiting from Amsterdam, and we had a large group of folks who love food, wine and friends.  We were not disappointed in my choice.  Tuba is in fact, one of the THE best restaurants I have eaten at in San Francisco.  The food is fantastic, flavorful and delicious and delightful.  The wait staff and owner are all incredibly helpful and friendly.  They know their food, they listen to their guests and they exceed expections.  The wine list is extensive.  There is something for everyone and all at a good price.  We had a mix of meat and various vegetarian dishes.  But, first they welcome you with plates of bread with olives, feta cheese and sundried tomato spread.  This is a complimentary and delightful surprise.  We were a large group.  We stood in the restaurant, walked around and chatted with one another as though we were in our own living room at home.  We started with a plethora of hot and cold appetizers.  Among our favorites were a zucchini pancake with dill, hand fried feta and spiced ground sirloin in bulgar shells.  We had much more and all were equally delicious.  Our entrees, shared family style included the BEST babaganoush I have ever eaten, fresh, creamy and flavorful.  We also enjoyed mixed kabobs, vegetarian mousakka and so much more!  As it turns our, our friend from Amsterdam is now dating a Turkish woman.  This was the perfect selection. I will return to Tuba again and again.  I am so happy we found this amazing restaurant.  I live in San Mateo, but it is worth the drive.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Service was very good. The food was good. I wouldn't say it's what you get in Istanbul, but it's very close. I would say the food in Istanbul always seemed so fresh. I didn't get that feeling here.They were a little skimpy on some things and the only real downside is the price- the food is good but it (along with overall experience) does not warrant these types of prices. I guess you have to shell out for overpriced food to get authentic Turkish food in SF (sigh).

SentimentText: So when I decided to do a date night with my wife I searched on Yelp for places near the movie theater and near her work in the Mission. After seeing the reviews of Tuba and being intrigued by the menu I made reservations. From the time we arrived until the time we left our experience was great! Our server and the entire staff was incredibly friendly. Her suggestions for Turkish wines were great and we enjoyed the 3 varieties that we tried. The food was great! We started off with the Mucver, which is pan fried zucchini patties with fresh dill. We then ordered 2 entries, the Beyti and the Adana Kebab. The Beyti (adana wrapped in lavash bread served with tomato sauce and yogurt) is somewhat like a pasta dish and was super rich!! The Adana Kebab (spicy ground sirloin and lamb) was perfectly prepared and paired with grilled vegetable and rice. Both entries left us very satisfied.As we ordered Turkish coffee we noticed a familiar face. As it turned out it was the owner, who we knew from Park Gyro (@ 9th and Irving). He stopped and talked to us for awhile and let us know about how he took the place over and how basically everyone who worked their was Turkish and that the chef recently arrived from Turkey. He ordered us a dessert on the house and thanked us for our patronage. The dessert, which was the Künefe (two layers of kadayif  filled with sweet cheese, baked to perfection and served with homemade syrup and pistachio nuts) was a great end to an awesome meal.Overall our entire experience was great and memorable and we will definitely be back again!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: My review is about service and food together.  The food is good, solid 3 stars. It is a good neighborhood restaurant.  It is small: i would suggest parties for not more than 6 people for 2 reasons: 1) the place is small and cannot be comfortably set-up for larger parties; 2) they do not have experience of serving large parties: the food takes a long time, and the service is not very efficient (again, it is lack of experience of serving larger parties, not the lack of trying). However, it is a very friendly place and they do their best to accommodate.  It is not cheap, but not too expensive. The portions are fair. Really good Turkish coffee.

SentimentText: I had a really, really great time at Tuba and definitely would come back! The service was SO nice (the owner waited on us) and the food is fantastic and you can't beat the price for the quality that you got. I learned that the owner brought his family recipes straight out of Turkey. Yum!First, the endless bread is great. Fresh and baked and soft, I still think about itThe menu is pretty diverse. We got the sigara boregi (fillo dough stuffed with potatoes), and falafel. The sigara actually reminded me of Chinese spring rolls. Both were flavorful.For dinner, we got adana kebab (skewered spicy ground beef), and someone else got the karides tava (shrimp sauteed with wine) which came on a skewer. Everything was authentic and tasty and the side veggies were portioned just right. I only wish we could have eaten more or left room for dessert.Next time!

SentimentText: What a shit show.Arrived at 8pm on a Friday night- we expected to have to wait. We put our name down and were told it would be a 45 minute wait. We went across the street and grabbed some beers. At 8:50 we came back- no table. At 9:10 I went in to have a chat with the person running the show about the fact that at this point, we had been waiting for more than an hour and nearly half an hour longer than we had been told the wait would be. Instead of any kind of concern or apology, I got a lecture about how they can't ask their guests to leave (there was a table of four that had finished their dessert half an hour previously). Finally, at 9:30 we gave up and went elsewhere. I wouldn't be so upset if it hadn't been for the horrible behavior of the host. Take your money to someplace that appreciates your business.

SentimentText: Tuba Restaurant helped me to throw a great retirement party for my friend. The food was delicious ( as it was the night I ate there with some friends to try it out). They circulated appetizers as  we stood and visited-- dolmas and a fritter of potato and cheese were yummy. The dessert of shredded fillo dough and honey and a cheese stands out as well as their baklava.Marel, the chef, met with me beforehand to make sure all the details of the food, the timing, and the physical layout of the restaurant would maximize the graciousness and fun of our affair. Her son Berk was there to help serve and fill in; Ismael, a  warm very  skilled waiter made sure that I could have fun at the party rather than get involved with the service. Both waiters were able to skillfully maneuver platters and drinks around our happy crowd before we sat down for the main meal. They felt like hosts and family by the end  of the party.  The main courses included a vegetarian  eggplant option with rice and carrots that was excellent.Tuba opened their restaurant for us to have this private party during a time they normally are closed. I really appreciated their flexibility and their desire to accommodate our needs. They worked within my budget; some other places I had called would have charged me that amount simply for the use of the room before the cost of food and drinks was included! This party was an all-around success and I would recommend Tuba for dining out with one friend or for a large private party-- for the quality of the cooking, the gracious service, and reasonable prices.Thank you Tuba!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: So we went there without having reservations (oops! and on a Friday!), but the owner, Ali, was magically able to find us an amazing table anyways! The wine selection was pretty large, and the waitress suggested Turkish wines that my friends really enjoyed. The food was simply excellent. It was different from some of my other Mediterranean experiences, and I mean that in a good way - I'm not normally the biggest fan of Mediterranean food. I ordered the sauteed chicken, which was perfectly cooked, and juicy and served with an amazing tomato-based sauce. We even got desserts - they have a chocolate chip creme brulee that we all loved. The service was quick and helpful and very friendly. They made very good recommendations. The atmosphere was cozy - there were many bigger tables for groups of friends, but there were also many couples there on date night. We left feeling warm and happy and quite full!

SentimentText: I just had the pleasure of dining at Tuba.  From the wonderful appetizers and salads to the delicious entrees, I have to say it was a very satisfying experience.  We started out with the classic Falafel with Hummus, my go-to dish in any middle-east restaurant.  The falafel came out as disks rather than balls, presented nicely around an island of hummus.  The bread that comes with it was not your standard pita halves.  It was clearly made on site and was more delicate and flavorful than standard pita.  We also ordered the cold meza,  Turk Salatasi, a health salad, which is a mixture of cucumbers, tomatoes and onion with lemon juice and a bit of Olive Oil.  I thought the splash of lettuce greens was a nice touch.  Finally, we ordered the signature dish Hünkar Begendi, which is pureed eggplant with mozzarella cheese and chunks of lamb floated on top.  Since it was eggplant, I was expecting something along the lines of a baba ganoush but it was far better.  The flavor was more complex but subtle.  The lamb was perfectly prepared, well cooked but tender.  Finally, the baklava for dessert was a great classic way to end the meal.  Try the Turkish tea to see the fun of the presentation.  All in all a great meal.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: We ate here for the second time last night, and I decided to write a review because I want these folks to succeed. This space has been the death of a number of restaurants in the time I've lived nearby so I'm hoping Tuba can make a go of it. It's delicious and the people are lovely.We started off with the hot appetizer platter for the table. All of it was delicious. The things that really stood out were the crab cake and the Mücver which is a shredded zucchini patty with cheese. Delicious flavor and texture. We also liked the Sigara Boregi which are little cheesy egg roll like things made of deep fried filo.The absolute gem of a main course though has to be the little meat dumplings called Manti. OMG. Delicious. Perfectly toothy texture, with a lovely amount of a tomato based meat sauce with yogurt. I could eat platefuls of this stuff. SO good. The menu says it takes an extra 20 minutes but it's SO worth it. Really nice service and very friendly. Highly recommend this place.
Label: Genuine

Based on the yelp reviews and a taste for something different we chose this place, and it turned out to be a great find.An older gentleman greeted us and asked if we had reservations. We didn't and he said there would a 30 minute wait, which we were okay with. We noticed a couple of empty tables and when he saw us looking he immediately apologized and said people had reserved them. No worries, but we appreciated the info. We were however seated shortly after since another party was 20 minutes late...a no show.The food was wonderful, the staff friendly and they graciously brought more bread with the side of feta, olives and wonderfully spiced butter without us asking. Water glasses were filled before reaching empty and they checked on us several times throughout the evening.All three of us ordered lamb dishes that were cooked to perfection. One word of caution is if you don't like hot or spices in your food than this isn't the place for you.As for dessert, I'd recommend the kannefe with unsweetened turkish coffee...though I thought the coffee was on the milder side. Otherwise, a satisfying evening.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Just went on a date with my husband, and we loved this place.  Tuba is a warm, friendly Turkish restaurant owned by a lovely Turkish husband and wife.  The food is gorgeous, especially if you like a little spice.  We started with the Icli Kofte (a signature app -yum!) and ended with the Turkish coffee (strong, smooth, quite a kick) and rice pudding.  Everything was delicious, fresh and flavorful.  A great local Mission gem - we'll be back soon!

SentimentText: I would eat there again. I didn't love it, but it was good.I ordered the moussaka, which was bland, but maybe moussaka IS bland.Maybe that's like saying macaroni and cheese is bland-I don't know.I was trying to avoid eating an animal, because we can assume life sucks for an animal being processed for death. And then the anxiety when the kill is imminent; that's gotta be bad.So I got the moussaka and watched my dc eat the chicken kebab. It looked really good. I kinda hoped it was dry.Anyway, my motivation to write this is to save your life.I went to find the bathroom. (These two things will come together.)There was a little alcove, and a closed door with a bathroom sign on one side. On the other side was an open door. It was dark, I couldn't see what was in there. I noticed a white towel hanging against the wall, and I figured it was a utility room or another bathroom.Before checking, I tried the handle of the bathroom door.Locked, so I turned towards the open doorway to see if it WAS a bathroom.By pausing for that one moment my eyes adjusted to the darkness and I saw that inside this doorway was a staircase...going down. Descending, I believe it's called, and it looked like a sudden descent, with paraplegia, possibly quadriplegia, or concussion and cracked rib maybe, at the bottom.I was grateful I left with just a bland moussaka experience.Don't walk through the door to your right.

SentimentText: Tuba is simply a gem! I love Mediterranean /Middle Eastern cuisine and Tuba definitely fulfill this craving.  Couple weeks ago, I had to plan a special event for my parents, Plan A didn't happen so Plan B is to have the party catered last minute. I called Tuba because I love their food and I know that my guests will be happy. Jay came through big time. Met up with him in the restaurant and put together a scrumptious menu for 18 people. Appetizers we had, Dolma, Ezme, Haydari, Sigara and Mucver - excellent combo and everything tasted soooo yummy!Entrée - Chicken Kebab - really moist flavor is goodLamb Chops - grilled tender tasty chopsAdana Kebab - spiced sirloin beef and lamb - My fave!!Dessert - Baklava - perfect to end the feast

SentimentText: I really want to give this place a higher rating but I just can't. The food just wasn't satisfying.We came here on a double date night and had a good time. The reservation process is easy and flexible. The ambiance here is peaceful. I think it's perfect for date nights. It has a good intimate yet comfortable setting. The service here is good too. All staff members were more than willing to describe the menu and help us decide what to order.For appetizers we tried the: 1) Ezme - crushed walnuts, pepper paste, tomato paste, garlic, cumin 2) Crispy Falafels - drizzled with tahini sauce3) Mücver - pan fried zucchini patties with fresh dill  For our entrees we had:1) Adana Kebab spicy ground sirloin and lamb2) Köfte Kebab ground beef and lamb, fresh herbs3) Manti (some kind of meat dumpling)For the appetizers, we all liked the falafels but none of us enjoyed the Ezme. The fact that it was a cold appetizer didn't help either. I didn't try the Mucver, but my boyfriend said he wasn't a fan. Our friends seemed to enjoy it though.For our entrees. I had the Adana Kebab while my boyfriend had the Kofte Kebab. Both were alright but we have had better. The meat was well cooked and everything but I just didn't get nearly as much flavor out of it as I wanted to. My boyfriend felt the same with his Kofte Kebab. Our friends had the Kofte Kebab and the Manti.  I tried the Manti and it was good but I wasn't crazy about it. This dish was one of the restaurant's specialties. Overall I think the ambiance and service is good, but the food is lacking. I can tell they have put a lot of effort into their food and while the quality is great, the flavor is just not enough. The pricing was fair. It was about $15 for each kebab and about $6 for each appetizer.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I came here with a friend for a drink before heading to the Academy of Science.The interior of the place could make you stay there for hours. We sat by the window as the sun was setting and I could definitely imagine being on a date here.The crowd is somewhat older and mellow which I like and the atmosphere is very sophisticated.The service is friendly but not overbearing. We ordered a glass of wine, hummus and the crab cakes appetizers. All absolutely delicious. I haven't been back since but I've been dying to. It's one of those neighborhood favorites. I recommend anyone, no matter what type of palate, go in and try this place. You will not be disappointed.

SentimentText: The first 2 times I went to Tuba I loved it.  A good friend and I had gone last year for my birthday & hers.  We had the lamb shank which we both loved, the walnut red pepper spread which we also loved & several other dishes.  A nice extra was that they gave us a free desert and a gift certificate for $20 off for each of our birthdays.  The owner also stopped at our table  to help us select dishes.  We went back for my birthday on a Monday night & were both disappointed.  We learned that they only have lamb shank on the weekends so we got the seafood special.  It was good, but not as good as the lamb shank. We also got the filo appetizer with a potato filling, which was greasy.   And we got the walnut red pepper spread again but it just tasted hot with almost no walnuts.  We returned it & got a salad instead which was not bad. But the waiter didn't tell us that both the filo appetizer & the entree came with salad so we had a huge amount of salad left over.  They also didn't give us a free dessert or a gift certificate.  Very disappointing.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: AmbianceThe host was welcoming and helpful.  The tables in the middle of the room are oddly organized and a bit cramped, but the food definitely makes up for it.AppetizerTuba Hot Platter: I wish I could love this appetizer, but the items on this dish were not hot.  The Mucver were cold in the middle.  The items on this dish were definitely frozen then cooked again.   The falafel was absolutely DELISH though. It had a pleasantly surprising spiciness to it.Main: Hunkar Begendi:  Very TASTY entree.  I loved the smokey flavor of the eggplant and saltiness of the lamb cubes on top.Kofte Kebab:  Perfectly cooked and seasoned.  Not too salty or dry.  I loved the grilled peppers that were added to this dish.  Dessert:  Pyramid Noisette Chocolate: Not too sweet with a little bit of crunch on the bottom.  Really loved the hard texture of the chocolate covering and then the chocolate creamy texture in the middle.  A perfect end to our meal!

SentimentText: I love Tuba. I love it so much, it made my list of restaurants to go to when I was back in San Francisco for a week. I especially love the pureed eggplant with lamb dish. It has smokey mozzarella mixed into the eggplant, with roasted pepper and tomato on top. The lamb is really tender too. The vegetarian Moussaka is also delicious, covered in cheese with potatoes, eggplant, tomatoes, and spinach. The entrees are priced around $8-14 per plate. The restaurant is very classy, with a warm, comfortable atmosphere. The wine is pretty decent and reasonably priced at $6-10 per glass. It's almost never full on a weeknight, but come with a reservation on Friday or Saturday. Good service, comfortable space, great food, better prices, and an overall great experience.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: YUM!!!  Early Valentine's dinner.Shared the pistachio crusted prawn salad and the falafel to start.  The prawns were so fresh and delicious.  Lightly crusted and fried perfectly.  Went perfect with the salad that had a simple olive oil/lemon dressing.  Falafel was good as well - four decent sized ones that came with... the same salad (minus shrimp).  Oh well.Entrees - hubby had the chicken shish kebab.  Perfectly seasoned chicken cubes on a skewer.  Amazingly tender.  Came with the same salad (argh) and rice.I had the stuff salmon with fume sauce (light cream) and rice.  Of course, if you look at the menu, the question is... what is it stuffed with?  Sauteed spinach, but it's not stuffed. It's layered on top of the salmon.  You see that lemon wedge on the plate?  Make sure to give that sucker a good squeeze all over the dish.  It is incredibly delicious and it will be hard for me to order anything else the next time we come here.The service was very friendly.  We had a nice conversation with our server.  Overall a very nice early Valentine's dinner and evening out.I really recommend this place.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Om nom nom.Having recently moved back to SF after spending some time in Turkey, I've been enjoying the smorgasbord of food options in our fair city. However, sometimes the Turkish food craving kicks in, and you gotta satisfy it.I've been exploring the Turkish places in the city, and while I haven't made it to all of them yet, Tuba is the best thus far.Wandered over on a Thursday evening, and it was busy, but not packed. They were playing all the classic Turkish pop songs, so I was pretty pleased the moment I walked in.I was even more pleased to see they not only have Efes, but they also have Efes Dark. SCORE. I hated Efes by the time I left Turkey, but now that I'm back in America and it's no longer the only beer option, seeing Efes on a menu makes me super happy. Being the "expert" on Turkish food, I was put in charge of ordering, so I opted for a sampling of mezes, as those are my favorite.Cevizli Ezme: Delicious with bread. Kizartma: One of my favorite Turkish dishes, and it was pretty tasty here.Sigara Böregi: I can't seem to find good ö outside of Turkey. It was okay, but not the best. If a restaurant starts serving spicy potato börek, I may change my mind.Mücver: Pretty good, kind of hard to mess up.Midye Tava: We ordered too much food, so by the time the mussels came, we were both full and feeling terrible. We managed to have a few, and they were good, but couldn't finish them. Mussels don't really keep well, either, for leftovers. Bummer.We did get some Turkish coffee, which was the perfect way to cap off the meal. I don't know if they had çay, but I may get that next time too.There's still a whole menu of things I need to try, but I think in the future, I'd go with a big group in order to sample all of the items.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Top notch experience! I went there with my husband and we were warmly greeted by owner and staff, and given a good table. Service was quick, attentive and the staff responsive.Food was amazing and generously portioned! Appetizer was healthy and yummy. For my entree, I felt like I was back in Istanbul, enjoying a juicy,well seasoned, grilled kefta. Desert, the Knafe, was deliciously warm and sweet, and we were served Turkish coffee, with pride, by the owner himself.The ambiance was lively, and thriving. Clientel is mostly non-Muslim, despite the food being halal. Yes they serve wine, but I was there to eat and wasnt particularly bothered by it.The owner takes pride in his work and is humble in his service... I will always stop there any time Im in SF.

SentimentText: Ohh sooooo good!! This place has been 3 blocks away for so long and it took a ScoutMob deal to make me realize. Absolutely delicious. Hummus, babaghanough and fried feta cover the familiar regional food, but kebabs, grilled meats and aromatic rice are so tasty and different. Perfect for date night or a place to bring parents!

SentimentText: I've been living rurally for 8 years, and have been without choices of restaurants. I lived in Turkey 15 years ago and claim the cuisine as my favorite. So obviously I was eager to remind my palate of the joys of Turkish food. Tuba was perfect!  The warm moody atmosphere calms the eyes and prepares the palate for exciting sensations. The staff is friendly, efficient and fun. The food is presented like art, and went beyond my expectations. Yes it is authentic Turkish, but it has a clean, crisp, fresh California quality that takes the traditional world cuisine to new scrumptious dimensions. Entrees are huge, so I suggest either doing meza's or having just the entree. We brought the rest back home and will have Tuba Turkish again tonight. I plan on visiting weekly!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Add us to the list of 5-star fans. We stumbled upon this restaurant via OpenTable looking for a place in the Mission on a Saturday night. We wanted something new instead of the old favorites. Now a new favorite.We're not much for meat and there is plenty on this menu to chose from. Two of us shared the cold appetizer platter and the mussaka. The mussaka was lovely and creamy. A terrific comfort food on a cool evening. The cold platter is a nice tasting of everything. Lots of fresh combinations, very fun and engaging. I like food that is more interesting than fussy and this place fits the bill. They brought extra bread with the appetizer platter, but you don't need it - they just fine to eat on their own, but the bread is good.The one thing we found not particularly good was the rice that came with the Musakka, but honestly, no loss - didn't need it anyway.Will definitely go back and you could bring friends who aren't particularly adventuresome about food and they could find something to love. Definitely a value in a city that can sometimes be short on them.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: good restaurent:)a group of friends and I finally got around to try this place last night, and we had, overall, a nice experience here.since there were 5 of us we ordered quite a lot of dishes. we tried their feta shrimp, tuba hot platter, shrimp scampi, sautee chicken, salmon, manti (beef dumpling) and lamb chops. they were all great. I might say this because i am not used to eating turkish food, but if anything, it was at least a great start.lamb chop was fantastic, it was tender, perfectly seasoned thought one of my friend didn't agree. everyone else seemed very happy with their dishes as well.their pyramid chocolate desert was quite memorable, what a presentation!

SentimentText: I have eaten every dish on the menu, and they are all a culinary vacation for my taste buds.  The flavors of roasted vegetables, lemon, cumin, garlic, and other fresh herbs are found in the roasted meats and vegetables, the delicious sauces and dips.Nothing comes from a can in this place, and the food really is sensational.The service is exceptionally friendly and attentive.  We NEVER go home disappointed, and are always eager to return.

SentimentText: I was skeptical to give this 5 stars (lets say 4.5 stars), but for a casual local joint, and considering I'm not really a fan of this type of cuisine, I was surprised.  This will def be a local spot to hit in the Mission!Got a slew of apps, and we couldn't finish them all...the only that was off was the falafel but it was ok.  The dolma was def the best I've had...my sidekick despises dolma and didn't cringe at this one.   For a main I got the stuffed salmon, and this was terrific.  Great sauce, with a creamed-like spinach on the perfectly baked fish...yum!  And a side of rice...it was just rice, why couldn't I stop eating it?  The desert was their sig dish (can't remember the name), and it was a flaky sweet savory heart attack.  I wouldn't get again because it was too rich, but will def try others on the menu.  Capped off the night with a Turkish coffee which I've never had.  They spin it before serving, which I thought was gimmicky; however, we noticed the sludge at the bottom of the glass after finishing and realized it's probably needed to centrifuge out this potent bean.The staff was friendly, the portions were big...I don't know how you'd judge this, but I'm on a mission to put on about 5 to 7 lbs people, and have been eating like a pig.  I couldn't finish the fish and went til I couldn't go anymore.   The only tacky thing was the lame wall art.Great find in the hood and will be back again soon!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: The kebab was very good.  The lamb chops were not as tender or flavorful as other reviewers gushed.  The stuffed falafal salad is humongous and makes a meal for one or an appetizer for 2-3.  They have a number of vegetarian options, including salads, eggplant dishes, and lentil soup. It's good for a date night type restaurant -- dark, red, and not too loud to carry on dinner conversation.  The seats have really high backs, which makes your table feel more private or secluded from others.  You're paying some amount for the ambiance and a huge wine list.

SentimentText: A friend and I arrived for an early dinner after a long day in San Francisco.  We were immediately given a choice of tables.  After a glance around at the surroundings, we settled on the window seat.  A plate of free bread was quickly served.  The sides of olives, cheese and seasoned butter paired deliciously with the bread.  When we finished the bread, our server promptly asked if we would like more.  The bread was delicious, but maybe a bit too filling.  We quickly declined the offer to save room for our main dishes.  We'd ordered the Sigara Boregi and Kofte Kabobs to share between two people.  The Sigara Boregi was amazingly delicious.  They came piping hot, served with a salad and a yogurt cucumber dip.  The dip was the perfect for bringing a feeling of cleansing coolness to a crisp pan fried pastry.  The Kofte Kabobs was a plate that came with four succulent pieces of perfectly seasoned grilled beef and lamb, a grilled tomato and pepper, rice and marinated onions and julienned carrots and cucumbers.  The onions gave a spicy edge to the kabobs.  The rice softened the salt.  The food was amazing.  The portions here was quite large.  We were quickly filled by the shared entree and appetizer (and didn't get to try dessert).  Our server was social, but knew how to give enough space.  We left very satisfied.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: My husband and I ate here on a Friday night - HIGHLY suggest reservations. The food was outstanding - We started with an appetizer - spinach, yogurt and garlic served with bread and feta, olives and herbed butter. Very nice dish. I had the Karides Tava, which is shrimp sautéed with wine, garlic asparagus, olive oil, and lemon juice, and was lovely. Very light, very flavorful. My husband had the Sarma Beyti Kebabi -- Adana kebab wrapped in lavas bread and topped with tomato and garlic yogurt sauce -- also wonderful and flavorful. And we capped the meal with their signature dessert: Künefe layers of kadayif (shredded fillo dough) filled with sweet cheese, served with homemade syrup and pistachio nuts. You can have it with ice cream, we opted to leave it plain. It was delicious as was the Turkish coffee - I asked for it not to be too strong and medium sweet and it was PERFECT.It's a wee bit crowded, the tables somewhat closer than I like, but the atmosphere overall was very nice and relaxed. Our only quibble was the service was...strange. A waitress appeared almost immediately after we were seated to tell us the specials and then asked to take our order - being new to the restaurant, we needed more time to look over the menu, but she never came back. The owner/manager came over, asked if we wanted wine - we didn't - and then hovered a moment, so we figured he wanted to take our order, so we gave him our appetizer order and he said, "I will let them know" and left without taking our entree order. The appetizer arrived very quickly, but no one came back to take our entree order even though we still had the menus on our table. We were busy eating the appetizer and almost done with it by the time I realized our entree order hadn't been taken, so I told said something when our water was refilled and we finally made our order. The dishes arrived pretty quickly, so it wasn't like we were waiting forever for our food, but it was still strange. And the couple who was dining next to us had to ask repeatedly for a sharper knife to cut the lamb he had for an entre - the butter knife just wasn't doing the job even though the lamb was tender. So....great food...the service was strange for us, but not to the point that we wouldn't go back there again since we got our food in good time and it was all delicious (which is why we go to restaurants in the first place).
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Having traveled in Turkey for over 20 years now, I feel safe to say that excellent Turkish food, one of my favorite cuisines, makes me glad to have traveled in such a wonderful place.  Good Turkish food makes me homesick for my home away from home.  And Tuba Restaurant, because of its owner/chef Ali Yaldiz, is a place to go for real home cooked Turkish food with a twist.  Ali is Kurdish, as are many of the best Turkish cooks in Turkey, and since he originally hails from the SE of the country, his specialties represent some of the oldest foods in all of Anatolia.Ali has recently added a new addition to his comprehensive menu, PIDE, a delicious baked item that is a favorite with Turks, Kurds and visitors alike. PIDE begin as hand made dough, rolled thin, filled with an assortment of fine dry cured meats, special cheese varieties, vegetables and spices, crimped along its edges by hand, baked to perfection until just crisp around the edges but tender underneath, and served piping hot.PIDE is the quintessential Turkish menu item that is served at small cafes, large hotels and in famous restaurants throughout the whole of Turkey, along the Aegean, Mediterranean and Black sea coasts as well in large cities and small villages all over the interior.PIDE at Ali's Tuba Restaurant is as good as PIDE gets.  He uses the finest ingredients, as he does with all of his menu items, and prepares what may be the best PIDE that I have ever had in all of my years of experience with Turkish food here and in Turkey.It is no wonder why PIDE is such a favorite of Turks young and old, because when it is done right, nothing is so sublime.  Ali and Tuba Restaurant really offer guests a chance to enjoy this secret specialty without the travel and without the jet lag.  PIDE at TUBA -- It doesn't get any better!  ENJOY!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: The bottom line: I really wish the food had been better.I *love* Turkish food. I grow rapturous about humus. I adore the mezes, the salads, the kabobs. I've had great Turkish food at many restaurants, in many cities (though never actually in Turkey).Tuba was ... just fine. My husband had an interesting and unusual dish that was basically pureed eggplant with cubes of lamb on top. That was the only dish that stood out - the rest was fairly lacking in flavor or anything to distinguish them. I ordered the stuffed eggplant, which seemed to be stuffed with the same frozen peas, carrots, and corn medley that I buy at Trader Joe's. We started with the cold appetizer sampler which, again, with few exceptions, tasted like it could have been assembled from the TJ's dip counter. The humus was a big disappointment and just tasted like a can of chickpeas had been pureed with some garlic.The good stuff: the restaurant has a great, cozy, romantic atmosphere. The waitstaff is friendly and attentive. That eggplant/lamb dish was yummy. I would go back to sample the kabobs (which many other yelpers rave about), but with so many other fantastic Turkish/Middle Eastern restaurants in SF (A La Turca, Troya, Fattoush) I'm in no hurry.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: This was actually a really good meal!  We even bumped into a couple of friends who were regulars.  I ordered the shrimp kebab - two skewers of 4 tasty shrimp with lemon and pepper, with rice, yogurt, peppers and julienned carrots and zucchini.  It was really good.  For dessert, I had my favorite, baklava, which was gooey and sweet (as it should be).  I deducted a star only because my friend's dish was just drenched in a large pool of reddish oil and he spent a long time dredging the meat and sauce out from under it (it might have been a sautéed chicken).  Another friend ordered the moussaka which is vegetarian here (she was excited about that), and very creamy and cheesy (which she enjoyed).  Overall, it was pretty good, and the ambience is cozy and warm.

SentimentText: According to Wikipedia "the tuba is the largest and lowest-pitched brass instrument". So, I won't lie, I had expectations of being greeted by a 15 piece brass band at the door. They must have been on a break when I got there.... but the lovely and authentic Turkish meal that followed more than made up for it.The mixed grill was well seasoned, the aubergine dip was deliciously smokey and the icli kofte was nice and crisp on the outside but moist and rich on the inside (just served a little too cold, my only criticism on the night).Will definitely be back again, maybe the tuba band will be there to greet me next time....
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I have had virtually everything on the menu at this point, so I suck for not having written a review until now. That said, I have a lot of data to draw on for you! Although this place is technically Turkish, the food is very similar to Greek and other Middle Eastern food.....in case you were wondering. However, here it is hands-down much better than most places I've been....and I have been a food-obsessed/gardener/cook/eat-out-a-lot person for the 20 years of my adult life. There is just something about the quality of the food and the way it is lovingly prepared at this place.This is my first five star review for a reason - it's consistently very high quality, the portions are huge, the service is really good and often the chef will come out and check to see how you are doing. The ambiance is pretty nice too, although the only knock I can possibly think to give it is that sometimes it gets a little too packed with people and then it gets too hot because the kitchen is going full steam...but they will open the front door if no one objects.OK, let's start with the service: very attractive and sweet female servers (I believe they are all Turkish too), super helpful at picking out wine from their extensive list, I have also seen then handle a couple of difficult situations with grace and leaving the customer feeling good.The food: did I mention HUGE portions? You can easily get full on the appetizers and amazing bread, but be careful not to because you really want to leave room for the rest of it. The lamb is always cooked to perfection, the shrimp is succulent and good in every dish it is in - but especially the Pistachio Crusted Prawn Salad, their falafel is not too dry and full of flavor, I loved their zucchini appetizer and the lentil soup....I even tried their eggplant dish with my friend who is veggie and liked that (and I don't usually care for eggplant unless the flavor is completely masked.)When should you try this place? Any time you have people in your party who are vegetarian, vegan, picky or indecisive - I've been here with all of these types and everyone has left happy and full. Also, just come here for a date or when you want one meal to last you for three in leftovers. I've been here going on 10 times in the past year. Enough said.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Turkish cuisine can be one of the Wonders of the World.  I happily traveled my way through this country several times, meals scattered between hair raising taxi rides, stimulating public bus transportation and nonstop encounters with friendly, inquisitive Turks eager to feed me. This comfortable restaurant is fine, but for its price it fails to introduce its guests to the best addictive and unique culinary experience that Turkey offers. We sampled the meza so we could sample all of the cold appetizers. The Hummous and grape leaves were no better than those available elsewhere.  However, the Cevizli and Kizartma (eggplant) were delicious. In a traditional Turkish neighborhood place, you would be invited into the kitchen to view and sample. The special of the evening was leg of lamb; two of us ordered it. Others ordered the Mussakka, sautéed shrimp and stuffed eggplant.  The lamb special came was well received (I didn't sample it). The sautéed shrimp , Mussakka and stuffed eggplant were also good, but doesnt the price demand something special?  Mussakka is a standard option in many Turkish and Greek restaurants, and this one was tasty, but again, was it distinguishable from the same dish served at other places?  The stuffed eggplant is also a classic dish which was well prepared.  My guests enjoyed the sautéed shrimp, but we wondered if it was a Turkish dish: not sure. The tab (including 2 glasses of wine and 2 turkish coffees) came to around $270 not including tip. I would recommend Tuba for those who want nicely prepared Turkish food in a comfortable setting, but after 3 trips here, I feel it falls short for its price. While not as comfortable, the offerings at Gyro King (especially the lunch specials) and Ala Turca are just as satisfying at a third the cost.  The truth is, I have yet to discover a Turkish restaurant that can match almost any Turkish truckstop wher you can sample an astonishing array of unique dishes not found here.  And where is the casual, family friendly Turkish neighborhood place that enthusiastically invites you into their kitchen, that asks you to smell and taste from their trays of colorful dishes?x
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I was thoroughly impressed with this place. We had a group of four so we did family style so we could sample a lot of the dishes: Appetizers: Ezme and Sigara Borei The Sigara was delicious. They were like these scrumptious, feta-filled egg rolls. The Ezme, which was a spread you put on pita, was pretty good but there's probably better options.Entrees: Lamb Chops and Mixed GrillAll very moist and tasty. The lamb chops were certainly the star.Dessert: KünefeI've never tasted a better dessert in my life. I'm not kidding. I was thinking about this dessert into the next day (mostly about how I can reverse engineer this dish and make it at home). It was sooo good: crispy sugar-glazed filo dough, gooey, savory cheese, and crushed walnuts and pistachios. You couldn't invent a drug to target more human pleasure receptors.

I guess Old McDonald lost his farm to us last night.

SentimentText: I'm a huge fan of Persian food. Though the cuisines are similar, I had never had Turkish, so my cousin suggested that we meet here. It's located on busy Guerrero St., and visiblly close to the corner of 22nd St. I found a parking spot on the next block. What I love about SF - are little pockets of businesses/restaurants at intersections such as this one - a little urban oasis nestled in between The Mission and Noe Valley.I walked into a really cozy, yet modern space, with no more than a dozen to a dozen and a half tables, maybe. The walls were colored a deep, warm red; the tables and chairs were made of dark wood; the really chic lighting and pops of colorful art really made the aesthetics inviting and comfortable. The server came by to take our drink order, and was taken aback, and perhaps offended that I wanted a Turkish coffee before dinner. She said that it wasn't too great for digestion...yet she doesn't realize that I've had it before, and drink coffee as easily as I drink water! I still asked for it.There was flat bread on the table, and it wasn't pre-packaged, or dry, compared to anywhere else that I've had it. It had a really great texture, yet was soft, and moist, like homemade American bread.My companions had ordered the hummus (which came with more flat bread), and it was super creamy, smooth, and the BEST that I have ever tasted. You could tell from the texture of it that it was "super homemade." ...and I now realize that most places probably have it pre-packaged.  It also wasn't oily and didn't have the puddle on the top like you find at other restaurantsFor my entree, I ordered the Adana Shish -Spicy ground sirloin and lamb at $15. I tried to order it extra spicy, but understandably, they couldn't do it because the meat was pre-mixed/pre-prepped with the spice.Shockingly, my entree arrived before I had a chance to finish my Turkish coffee! I'd say it was less than 15 minutes to wait for my food - which was cooked to order, and nice and hot.The shish was really super moist. It came with a grilled tomato, a grilled chile pepper, a large (but not overkill) serving of rice, onions, dill yogurt sauce, and of course, the shish kebab at maybe a foot long. Note that the beef/lamb meat combo is usually a really good flavor combination because you don't get that overpowering taste from the ground lamb, yet, you also get the natural beef fat from the ground sirloin to juice-it-up. Since I asked for extra spice, they served me up with a helping of hot sauce! All-in-all, it was enough food to keep you full in the stomach, yet not so much that it sends you over the edge with a to-go box to boot!For dessert, I ordered Baklava $6), which I NEVER pass up. The layers of filo were thin and flaky, which was good, and had some honey in it. This was definitely one of the best I have ever tasted, and not dry like I've had at most places.To summarize, I would have given this place five stars if it weren't for the mediocre service. Not to the fault of anything or anyone, with the exception of circumstance, there was a slight language barrier with the server. Note that this is NOT a criticism. It's merely a trivial thing yet at the same time, a large enough interaction for me to remember it.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Tuba is very easy to review: great venue; great people and service; great food; and a really, really great price.   The owner and staff are warm, friendly, competent people.  They made it clear that they wanted me to enjoy my meal and I certainly did.  It's really a shame that local restaurant reviewers don't review places like Tuba, as places like this are what make a city great for people who appreciate food.  I started with the very nice, thick and hearty, lentil soup.  What was very good became great when I squeezed some juice from the lemon on the plate into the soup.   Wonderful start to a meal.  I almost forgot to mention the great bread that comes to your table gratis.  The spread, cheese, and olives that accompany the bread are a treat.  For a main course I had the mixed grill.  I am an expatriate New Yorker and almost a walking food compactor.  Yet even for me there was enough great food on this plate to have shared.  The chicken kabob was moist and perfect. The lamb kabob and lamb chop were very good.  Likewise the kofte and adana.  Of note, the rice and dip that accompanied the meats were great and the onions and carrots were perfect and perfectly wonderful.  The Turkish wine suggested by my pretty young server paired very well with my meal.I left feeling good about the world.  And all because of Tuba.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Cute little Turkish restaurant with good service and pleasant decor.  The food is tasty and quite hearty.  I had the adana kebab, half of which ended up boxed to go.  The Turkish coffee I had after my meal was pretty good too.  Standard.    Why only three stars?  It felt pretty damn cramped in there.  The aisles are small and just getting to and from my table was not graceful.  I had to dodge a waitress on the way in, and be mindful of the way my purse swung on my way out.  If the edge of my chair wasn't getting knocked whenever someone walked by our table, my companion's elbow was.  Just moving a chair across the room was a major to-do for one of the waitresses and everyone had to make room as she passed.  There were simply too many interruptions throughout the evening due to the tight spacing.  Then there was the noise level.  It got a little over the top several times while we were there.  Perhaps the fact that we were seated so close to other tables may have had a little to do with it.  Whatever it was, I lost my train of thought several times while speaking and we had to repeat ourselves more than a few times to hear each other across our own small table.  Parking in that 'hood is not easy to come by either.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: We decided to try Tuba since it was on our list of to trys and the pics of their food looked sooo good.Plus we had Scoutmob which helped the cause even more. Everything was sooo good. Me n the BF ordered the mixed grill, Turkish tea and coffee. Everything was fresh and came out out in a timely fashion. The wait staff was attentive and cordial as well. We shared the plate and it was more than enough. The mixed grill is awesome considering it has a little of every thing they have on the menu in it and the rice is to die for or maybe i just thought so since we been on a health kick and I hadn't had rice for like a month so I ate it like it was a serving of candy. We will be back!

SentimentText: My friend and I went to this place for the very first time just this past Sunday.  We had no reservations and her little two-year old with us.  When we arrived the place was packed and there was about a 45 minute wait.  As badly as we wanted to wait, we simply did not have the time.  As we started to head back to the car, the owner ran out and told us that if we sit tight for just 10 minutes he would make the room to accommodate us and that's just what he did.  From the first impression all the way to last, we were amazed.  The food, presentation and atmosphere were outstanding but what really stood out is how the owners and staff made us feel like family.  It's hard to find an experience like this and when you do, it's very memorable.  Of course we learned our lesson for next time...make the reservation regardless the day or time.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I was greeted with warm and friendly service on a Saturday at 6:30pm. Around 7-7:30pm, the restaurant filled up. The small and intimate size and deep red walls makes the ambiance cozy. As I waited for my cousin, the owner talked to me and was very nice. I started with a glass of wine, while I perused the menu. I wanted to try a Turkish white wine, and so the server described the 3 that they have, so I chose the Kavaklidere Cankaya, like pinot grigio, which I liked. They started us with their complimentary bread with olives and spreads..mm..We shared the:1. Cevizli Ezme Walnuts, Turkish red pepper paste, tomato paste, fresh garlic, olive oil,and cumin  Signature meze (my favorite)2. Sigara Böregi Fillo dough stuffed with potatoes, feta cheese, parsley and a touch of black pepper3. Karides Tava Shrimp sautéed with wine, garlic, asparagus, olive oil, lemon juice with rice and veggiesAll were good though we talked so much and were in a rush to a comedy show, so they werenice to give us the bill and pack the food quickly.  I would come back to try other items.

SentimentText: Had last minute plans to head up to SF on a Friday night and decided to dine at Tuba Restaurant based on 1) availability on OpenTable, and 2) 1000pt reservation.AMBIANCE: Extremely dim inside the restaurant-- I guess they're going for a sexy/mysterious vibe, what with the lack of lighting and all the cushions.  The restaurant space is small, and was crowded when we arrived.  There is no dedicated waiting area, so the majority of diners waiting for a table have to huddle awkwardly by the door, or lurk next to someone's table. SERVICE: Friendly, apologetic... but... not the greatest.  For one thing, we arrived a few min early (5) for our 8:30PM reservation, only to be told by the owner (? An older gentleman) that he was so sorry, but we would have to wait a few minutes, on account of our early arrival.  Ok, NBD, we stand outside the doorway like awkward creepers and check out their menu.  We ended up waiting for over 15min before I requested to be seated outdoors.  They quickly set up the table, and we ordered pretty much immediately upon sitting down.  It took them another 15min to bring us water, which they never refilled.FOOD: The food arrived lukewarm to cold at our table... which was quite unappetizing.- Falafel ($7): Very loosely packed falafels (4) with a small mound of hummus.  This app came out nice and hot, and was fairly satisfying.  I prefer a denser falafel but the flavor of these were good.- Mercimek Corbasi (bowl $7): Red lentil soup in a bowl was a decent sized portion, but did not come out quite as hot as I would've liked.  It had a pretty sour edge (the addition of the accompanying lemon wedge was a bit overkill)... the versions of lentil soup I had while in Turkey were never this sour, and were way more savory.  This was mediocre at best.- Sebzeli Guvec ($18): A lamb cube casserole with assorted veggies (zucchini, bell peppers, onion).  The lamb was really gamey, but the worst offense was that this dish was COLD.  J said his half was fine, but practically every bit I ate was ice cold in the center.  So unappetizing!  The side salad was nicely (lightly) dressed, and the rice was fine.OVERALL: Having to wait more than 10+min for a table when we had a reservation already put Tuba Restaurant on the naughty list.... The kicker was the COLD FOOD, which really turned me off from Tuba Restaurant and earned it a 2star rating.  Price seemed to be reasonable for SF (~$40 including tax+ tip for 2 apps & 1 entree), but I will not be returning.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I had a groupon which was about to expire so I last minute threw together an event. I made a reservation for 4 but due to classic SF flakerism, 2 people cancelled/no showed. I miss the east coast where people show up when they say they will. The place was packed so I was feeling anxious to get my food. We order the feta prawns to share as an app and for dinner, we get some sort of homemade meat stuffed pasta in cream sauce and plenty of bread (amazing btw). 1) The decor was not that impressive. We could have been in any fancy restaurant. It didn't scream Turkish culture. 2) Service was nice and friendly and always checked on us for water. They didn't bat an eye when I said 1/2 the party flaked. 3) Portions were a little skimp but w/ the bread, the pasta and app filled me up. I wouldn't come here starving though. 4) Prices are decent. 5) Good for a first date, as music wasn't too loud and the place is cute. I need to come back as this review is written months after the visit. There are several things I want to try on the menu as well. Maybe there will be a Townhog for this soon.
Label: Genuine
