SentimentText: A restaurant that surely entices and delivers with exceptional flavors, Tuba, which literally means, and I quote the son's owner,  "an upside down tree hanging from the heavens - to grant people an easy way to pluck its fruits" traverses Turkish and Mediterranean faire beautifully. There's plenty of vegetarian option, and a Sebzeli which is a wonderful plate of eggplant and veggies in their savory sauce. They also have kebab for the meat eaters. But a great selection of cold and hot mezes for both vegetarians and non-vegetarians to share. The place is spacious, so tables are certainly not on top of each other. Lastly, they serve super ice cold beer - great for a warm night.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I came in here Sat before last with a friend, and they were full, but cleared a space at the bar for us to sit.  We just had a few appetizers which were tasty, but not spectacular, but I think we ordered the wrong things, because other things went by that looked even better.  They were very nice however, and we sat there for ages drinking wine and talking, and everyone who worked in the restaurant stopped by and chatted with us.  They were so nice and friendly I decided to make reservations there for the next weekend for another friend's bday.  This time in a larger group we got real food.  The mixed cold appetizer plate was tasty, and I had split the lamb shank entree which was HUGE.  Even the two of us could not finish it.  Again, everyone stopped by the table to chat, and when they found out it was my friend's birthday they of course presented us with dessert, sang, etc.  And you know what it was really sweet, not at all like when I was a teenager and worked at Swensen's ice cream shop and I had to sing happy birthday to all the kids who came in for their birthday parties.  In my old timey Swensen's uniform, just dying of embarassment.    So Tuba, nice, friendly, tasty food.  Split the entree.  Good for birthdays.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: The food was authentic and delicious. The wait staff was very friendly. The un-authentic aspect of the restaurant was the typical "turn the tables" mentality. This doesn't happen in Turkey and Europe - the table is your's for the night. I was disappointed when the wait staff took everyone's plates while I was still eating and even gave them the dessert menus while I was finishing my meal.  We were served our desserts and the bill came immediately, before asking if we wanted a coffee or espresso, which, in my opinion, isn't a dinner out without an espresso.  Highly recommended if you're not as fussy as me about good waiter manners and service. Authentic food with American service.  Booooooo.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Wow, what a most delicious spot to dine accompanied by excellent service with a home style feel and taste.  I have been looking for a good Mediterranean Restaurant in the area but have been disappointed all too many times by the dried out meats served.  Tuba makes you feel like you are dining around the Mediterranean and exceeded my expectations.  Their lamb chops were juicy and exquisite!  The vegetables on the sampler plater were fresh and tasty.  The owners were a lovely couple who approached the tables and watched with a caring eye that their patrons were satisfied.  When I looked around the room everyone was smiling. I can't wait to go again!

SentimentText: Can't believe I waited this long to try Tuba! I had heard good things, but there is so much mediocre Mediterranean food in San Francisco, I figured it would be more of the same hum drum falafel and hummous. So wrong! We ordered a range of dishes from cold and hot mezes to salads and entrees. Everything was perfectly prepared and full of flavor. I've never been to Turkey but this seemed authentic in that the dishes did not seem to be "Americanized" but rather had interesting ingredients and flavors i haven't had at other Mediterranean places in the bay area. I encourage people to order things they don't recognize--you will be pleasantly surprised. We also had some delicious Turkish wines. Service was impeccable. We were with friends that we hadn't seen in a long time, and they allowed us to order slowly and were attentive without disrupting the flow of conversation. It also has a great neighborhood feel -- clean and warm, with a relaxed vibe. Will definitely be back.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Tuba makes me think of the huge musical instrument that a band member plays.  It's loud, somewhat obnoxious, and super intimidating.  However, Tuba, the restaurant, was nothing like the musical instrument.  I was quiet, very inviting and sensitive to me needs.  It seems like it would be a great date place.  Warm inviting colors and a very prominent Mediterranean theme made me completely comfortable.  I went to dinner with my friend Sameer Y. and began the night a glass of Turkish wine.  We followed that up with the Tuba Cold Platter, which i thought was delicious.  I loved the variety.  I would say there were about 7 different things on this platter.  Everything was tasty.  For our main course I had the Musakka and Sameer had the Stuffed Eggplant.  Both were delicious and super filling.  I have to say that their portions are quite generous.  Overall, this meal was satisfying and the service was great.  The only thing i have to warn  you about is that after eating here, i wouldn't suggest going out unless people around you don't mind Mediterranean food burps.  My burps were potent that night. eek! so embarrassing.
Label: Genuine

Try a turkish wine! A rarety! The whites are especially good if you like a dry, slightly mineral taste ( which I do).The food feels more like comfort food: hearty soups, thick sauces, grilled meats, all very tasty. Salads are excellent and huge.

SentimentText: How fortunate we were to wander in here after discovering that La Provence's "summer hours" mean that they're closed on Mondays and Tuesdays.  (Perhaps the owners actually go to Provence in the summers?)  We arrived at Tuba around 5:30 on a Tuesday, and were seated right away (certainly no need for reservations at that hour, though per other reviews, showing up later may warrant one).Upon entering, we were stilled by the dark wood and red walls, a grounding effect that welcomed the enormous and hearty dinner we were about to consume.  Starting with the cold sampler plate (impressive in its fresh taste and interesting variety including dolmas, zucchini salad, eggplant salad, hummus etc), coupled with the delectable feta prawns, I must admit that we were already getting full before the entree we were sharing (per our server's recommendation) arrived.  That stopped us not in the least, once our hearty mixed grill came.  Dang!  That's some good meat!  The Tuba mixed grill gave me a tromboner!!!  (So sorry, I couldn't help myself.)  Topped off with a fine Turkish wine, we were well pleased with our serendipitous find.  (Though not surprised at all when I came home and saw that Yelp loves Tuba.)  Staff are lovely, service was timely, bathroom is clean.  I have only great honking noises for Tuba.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: My friends and I decided to find a restaurant we wanted to try while in the city for a show, and we ended up here based on the location and wanting to try a different cuisine.  I called the restaurant first to confirm they had vegetarian options which they did.I actually expected it to be a bit run down and more self service based on the sign (yeah, I was imagining a order at counter - wait to pick up order kind of place).  I was surprised to see a nice welcoming and cozy atmosphere when we finally got there.It was not full by the time we were there, and that is surprising considering the food and service is exceptional!We decided to sit on the side with the pillows.  It was really comfortable considering the pillow was a good back support.After getting some recommendations, we ordered the hot plate as the appetizer and ordered 3 vegetarian plates and one salmon dish.  We ended up taking the salmon dish with us to go as we ended up running a tad close to the time our show was about to start.  It wasn't their fault since we got there with about an hour to spare and had ordered appetizers.  It ended up to be too much food anyway, so that was a good thing.They give you some amazing bread and spiced butter!  Again, the bread was AMAZING.  It was really flavorful and went absolutely well with the spiced butter they provided.   We probably got about 4 refills of it (talk about generous).  We got champagne also.  I decided to try the yogurt drink they had.  Boy was that rich.  It was definitely good for you, but it was really rich.  Quality for sure!  I had to share that with the table to finish the glass.  They were kind enough to bring small samples for each of my friends instead of me having to pour some into empty glasses.  That is really nice of them and thus, it goes to show how good our waitresses were.The dishes included two different types of eggplant selection, a falafel  salad, and a salmon dish.  All the dishes except the salad came with rice and salad as sides.  Great portions, and I must say, the rice was delicious.  Not sure how they cooked it, but it went well with everything we had ordered.After our show we ended up snacking on the left overs at one of the friend's place.  All in all, this was one heck of a find.  I will definitely go back here again.  Good food, great service, what more can you ask for.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Reserved using Open Table option was easy and no issues for a Sat 6pm.  The place feels like another world and is great with the pillows on the bench and traditional hookah in the front window.  Small and cozy, not great for large groups over 10.    Started with a pint of Stella, the beer selection was small, the wine more extensive.  Most of the menu I could not pronounce anything, but the staff did not seem offended at pointing and their constant explanation of what something was or how pronounce something was fun and educational.1)combination cold meza mini appetizers enough for 4 was a small combo of all the appetizers was a great start.  This went great with the warm diagonally cut bread was just perfect and flavorful.2)Special dinner entree was lamb shank with bulger (soft and gelatinous), soup and salad was killer good.  The best lamb I've even had, and I've even been to New Zealand known for their lamb.3)Water and bread was always filled, we felt so welcome and waiters were attentive but not overbearing.4) Dinner and drinks for two with tip under $100 with leftovers to take home is a great night.  We were in and out in less than an hour, but we did not feel rushed.5) Great safe location, free street parking after 6pm Sat was not badI would go back and bring more friends to try all the variety was a bit overwhelming because everything sounded so good and hard to decide what to order.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I don't even know where to start. I was excited for Turkish food, and I was starving. Unfortunately, the friend I was meeting here for dinner was incredibly late, so my mouth was watering as the servers brought dishes out left and right and none of them were for me.I have to say I like the dark red walls, and the opulent bar. However, I have to say the artwork was NOT in the Turkish theme at all. Warm blocks of color (albeit nice to look at) do not remind me of Istanbul or Ankara, not even close.Must-try on the menu:Dolma - the usual delicious combo of rice, currants and other flavors wrapped in grape leaves.Mixed Grill - great combo of 5 different kinds of meats: chicken, pork, lamb, beef, and something else I wasn't sure what it was but it was tasty. This dish is large enough for 2 if you're looking to share.The Malbec selection was great....if you're into red wine, trust me when it comes to Malbec. However, this is the one thing on the menu I ordered that wasn't Turkish.

SentimentText: We called for a last minute reservation on Saturday, and were told that they could seat us at 6:00, which would give us one-half hour to get there.The place is nicely decorated, the walls festively painted in orange.  Everybody there was super friendly. I ordered the special (catfish stuffed with crabmeat and bell peppers) and my partner ordered the salmon...both were delicious. The portions were fairly large...as we could have easily shared an entrée and an appetizer.  As much as we wanted to try a dessert...we were both just too stuffed.  The owner made a point to greet each table and asked how the food was.We sat by the register...and the only drawback was the loud volume when the telephone rang.  Otherwise...definitely a place to check out if you haven't already.

SentimentText: I came here for dinner with three others recently.  I really enjoyed the vegetarian appetizer sampler (Tuba Meze Tabagi)!  I shared the chicken kebabs (Tavuk Sis), which were good.  The owner brought out a few extra pieces of chicken on a separate plate and told us that the chef thought s/he had overcooked a few on the kebab.  However, the extra chicken, which was a nice gesture, turned out to be UNDERcooked and we didn't eat it.  One of the eggplant dishes (Sebzeli Patlican) was really tasty.  The bread they serve here is excellent, too! Friendly service; seems family-run.

SentimentText: I was pleasantly surprised - this is definitely a great Turkish restaurant, and a nice upscale alternative to the cheap places in the Loin.  I wouldn't have found this place but for Groupon, and I'm glad I did.Service was stellar.  I mean, absolutely outstanding.  Our server was incredibly warm, friendly and helpful, but not intrusive.  The soft, warm bread and herb butter were a nice start.  Lentil soup was perfect.  My manti was pretty standard - not exciting but I wasn't really expecting it to be, I just wanted manti, and I got it.  The mixed grill kebab sampler was. just. delicious.  Probably the best lamb I've had in years - moist, tender, and well-seasoned.  The chicken was standard.  The kofte kebab and adana kebab were perfect.  The accompanying rice was fluffy and delicious.The kunafa house special dessert was SO GOOD.  It's not like the kunafa I've previously had which is drier and more pastry-like (still delicious) - here, it's warm, layered with cheese, and dripping with honey.  Add a cup of Turkish coffee and you've got one of the best dessert experiences ever, hands down.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Came in on Friday as a last minute dinner option and had a great time.  The staff was warm and curious and made great suggestions.  The owner was involved and handed up two fantastic glasses of wine while we waited an extra ten minutes while our table was prepared.  And the food was fantastic.  I have passed this place 100 times driving and so glad we stopped.  Try the stuffed eggplant.  Amazing.

SentimentText: Great restaurant - been here twice. The send time because i was obsessing and craving for the food :) The first time we came here with friends and we ordered couple of the dips (yogurt dips are my fav and the one in tuba is delish), and shared the mousakka (they have a vegetarian one) with my friend. Its so rich and with the rice and yogurt dip, i couldn't ask for anything more. The meat eaters tried the lamb and chicken kebabs and nobody at the table was complaining.When i go to restaurants I try to have wines from the region of the restaurant and i did here too, but it was too full bodied (and earthy) for my taste, but that's just a personal thing. The service was amazing, both times. very friendly, great suggestions.But the highlight - kanefe! we tried to share it amongst 4 people the first time. Its a good thing, we didn't jump into a fight over that dessert. IT was incredible! ps: the dessert was the obsession, but the rest of the food holds up very well too.

SentimentText: I can't help but give Tuba 5 stars. Came here last night and still thinking about how delicious everything was. My b/f and I love going out in the Mission and this place happened to have a reservation open at 8pm on a Friday so we snagged it.  We started with the Cevizli Ezme, a cold Meze that is basically a delicious spread with crushed/pureed walnuts, red peppers, garlic, olive oil etc. They bring you endless amounts of warm wonderful bread with olives, feta cheese, and herbed butter. The Cevizli Ezme was so very flavorful and spiced perfectly. I could have been content just dipping my bread in that alone all night. We also ordered the crab cakes (I'm not sure how much of a Turkish dish that is) although still it was cooked just right, again very flavorful and came on top of a bed of greens that had a nice light dressing with hints of mint in it.We shared a main course called the Manti which was dumplings with garlic yogurt sauce and mint. Again, it was perfect and flavored so perfectly. We were so content and full and not ready to move yet we sat and stayed and had another drink. The waitress even got to me try some Turkish wine that was also really good (comparable to a Malbec). The waitress and owner were very friendly, the atmosphere is cozy but casual enough and their prices are extremely reasonable. Above all the food was delicious and full of flavor. I'm really looking forward to coming back!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: The review average place for this is the reason why I don't *really* use Yelp anymore to gauge the quality of restaurants.  Just think about it, how can an extremely mediocre restaurant with subpar food and service compete with the best of SF (who also have 4-star reviews)?  On the good side, food was clean (as opposed to dirty) and the portions were huge.  But the quality of flavors was so boring that I can barely recall what I ordered.  I was especially disappointed because I live 3 blocks away and am married to a "Middle Eastern" - so this had the potential of becoming a staple for us.Definitely would choose Old Jerusalem on Mission *any* day, for the price, authenticity, and food.  Tuba feels like a hack of a restaurant conceived by a rich landlord who doesn't truly care about food.  Unfortunately, there are quite a few of these in the city.

SentimentText: Came here with a group of friends.  We ordered several items to share: for appetizers, the mixed cold and the mixed hot plates, two types of salad, the salmon dish, beyti andana (ground sirloin and lamb wrapped in lavash bread served with tomato sauce and yogurt) and the mixed grill plate (sampling of all the meats).If it's your first time trying Turkish food, i recommend the mixed plates that the have--it's a great way to sample a little of everything.  It was all delicious although I would say the salmon was nothing special.  It was almost like creamed spinach over salmon.  Have to say that they have excellent presentation.Only complaint would have to be how close all he chairs were, on one table and then from table to table.  It was also quite warm inside, but fortunately cooled down after the sun went down.

SentimentText: My husband and I had a groupon for this place, and after tonight, I'm definitely got we got it and took the time to try it out! The waitress was friendly, but not the intrusive friendly type -- so you were well taken care of without being disturbed more often then needed.The food came out quickly. As an appetizer,  we shared "Mücver" ("pan fried zucchini patties with fresh dill")  which were really good. The portion was also generous and the plating -- elegant. Then almost immediately, we got our main meals. I had the lamb shish kebab, while my husband had the kofte kebab. Both were really tasty. I personally thought my choice was nicer, but the kofte kebab had more meat. Both were served with some nice rice and veggies. All of the food was fresh. And again, for those who care about aesthetics: plating was once more elegant. This might not be the best of the best in San Fran (haven't tried that many Turkish restaurants in the city though I have experience with this type of food), but I don't have a single complaint, and we were really pleased, so I'm giving it a full 5 stars. PS: prices are very reasonable.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I was craving some Mediterranean, but as a vegetarian, I'm usually relegated to falafels and Greek Salad.  So when I saw that the menu in Tuba had some unique options, my friend and I headed over for a meal.Location is great:  It's in the non-sketchy part of Mission, about a 5-10 minute walk from Bart and major bus lines.  Very pleasant walk after dinner amidst pretty houses.  It's a little quiet, so maybe parking is easier here, but my car is a Muni pass, so I wouldn't know.Ambiance: It is pleasant inside.  The decor isn't really Turkish, but is nice.  A great date location.  Waitresses were extremely friendly.Food:  YES!  They give everyone complimentary bread with Turkish-seasoned butter, and it was great!  My friend and I shared a zucchini yogurt appetizer (Kabak Ezme), which I had never tasted before and was so, so good!   We then shared 2 entrees:  the stuffed eggplant and the moussaka (their version is vegetarian!).  Both entrees were AWESOME and portion sizes were good - they came with basmati rice and salad.  We really wanted dessert but we didn't stop eating in time and were just too full.  But the sweet cheese stuffed phyllo w/ honey and nuts sounds amazing!Total cost was $42 w/ tax and tip.  Definitely planning to go back!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Cozy/crowded spot. We had dinner here on a Saturday night when we couldn't really agree on what to eat. Despite our reservation, we had to wait a while because it was absolutely packed. We had the sigara boregi (fried feta cheese) to start, he had the kofte kebab and I had the lamb shish kebab. Overall, good sized portions and pretty tasty. The bf commented that the kofte was not as good as two usual places he likes to frequent on the peninsula, but I still thought my lamb hit the spot. The main things I did not particularly enjoy were 1) it was so crowded, I was sitting closer to the woman next to me on the banquette than my dining companion (her conversation wasn't THAT interesting either), 2) it was so loud that I felt like I had to scream to have my own conversation (the screaming child across the room fit right in!). I could see me returning if I lived in the neighborhood because I did like the food, but likely won't bother.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Tuba fills the gap as an intermediary option between hole in the wall and spendy splurge restaurants. It is comfortable with enough elbow room and surprisingly pleasant ambiance. There's a nice buzz about the room but you don't feel like they are rushing to turn your table. Two lady friends and I decided to go with an array of appetizers and skip the less interesting entrees. We started with the Tuba cold platter and also split the hot platter and creamy indulgent feta prawns. This was quite the bounty to match a round of Turkish white wines by the glass and a bottle of budget-friendly sauvignon blanc. I'm a sucker for the lemony, tahini-rich, olive oil, garlic, tomato, and eggplant flavors of the Mediterranean, so I quite enjoyed our meal. The mezze heavy small plates are give you an opportunity to taste a lot of items and share with friends.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: We went here because our Groupon was about to expire. Had been meaning to try it for a while after reading some nice things about the place. We had the Moussaka and the Stuffed Eggplant. Both dishes were really tasty. However, we've never been to Turkey, so we're not sure of the authenticity, or lack thereof, that others on Yelp are complaining about. The unfortunate thing is that despite our liking the food here, we can only give the restaurant 3 stars. The woman at the front with the long curly hair who acted as our hostess and later as our waitress was quite rude. From the moment we arrived she did not greet us in a friendly manner. I told her our party size and she sniped back about whether we had a reservation. I told her no, and she acted like I was being a lot of trouble about it. The place was 60% empty at that point, but I get that others may have made reservations. If you're busy, it's fine, let me know and we'll find some other place that needs the business. She had the same attitude upon taking our order and taking the Groupon from us, even though we ended up tipping well on the pre-Groupon bill. They eventually accommodated us at a smaller table all the way at the back right next to the kitchen, even though there was a perfect sized table at the front window where it was much cooler. It was probably 88 degrees or so inside towards the back. There was a gentleman who served us our food and his attitude was just fine. They had set our table with 1 place setting, one napkin and knife, and one napkin. We let him know about the mistake when he presented our food and he was polite about it and got us what we needed right away.If I'm paying $13 for half an eggplant with some diced vegetables mixed in, please be nice to me. Based on the service we received from this individual I don't think I would go back just due to the chance she would wait on us again.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: First (and reflexively), I struggled whether to award the place 4-stars based on frantic annoyance at being misdirected and then having my damn smartphone 'tard out on me.  Or considering my taste buds dulled by the onset of a miserable cold. In the end, my 4-stars standard won out (and you can't give a half-star in yelp). The basics:  Well-prepared Turkish food (not the original Morrocan I craved, perhaps another ding factor....) served quickly;  a modest but well-thought out wine list (Yummy Russian River Pinot by the glass); lovely, inviting space made for a warm tonic to the chilly night.  The mezzas are yummy. The felafel is wonderfully green and crispy, and, best of all, served wide and round, a hallmark of handmade not prepackaged, and well-crisped.  My mis-drecting dining companion had a yummy set of vegetarian dishes: Ezme (crushed walnuts, pepper paste, et al) that complemented the felafel, and the Musakka.  My lamb kabobs were cooked to charbroiled perfection (moist).  The conversation was pleasant (except for the obnoxious indie-cred discussion by the table of mission hipsters.... When will these folks wither away?).In addition to the tasty food, the wait staff (hostess and waitress) were attentive and prompt.  The space is small enough that on busy nights it could fill up quickly, but the two handled the smallish crowd deftly.I will definitely be heading back, if only to indulge in the Künefe, the oft-mentioned phyllo-cheese pastry dish.
Label: Genuine
text1: first and reflexively i struggled whether to award the place 4stars based on frantic annoyance at being misdirected and then having my damn smartphone tard out on me or considering my taste buds dulled by the onset of a miserable cold in the end my 4stars standard won out and you cant give a halfstar in yelp the basics wellprepared turkish food not the original morrocan i craved perhaps another ding factor served quickly a modest but wellthought out wine list yummy russian river pinot by the glass lovely inviting space made for a warm tonic to the chilly night the mezzas are yummy the felafel is wonderfully green and crispy and best of all served wide and round a hallmark of handmade not prepackaged and wellcrisped my misdrecting dining companion had a yummy set of vegetarian dishes ezme crushed walnuts pepper paste et al that complemented the felafel and the musakka my lamb kabobs were cooked to charbroiled perfection moist the conversation was pleasant except for the obnoxious indiecred discussion by the table of mission hipsters when will these folks wither awayin addition to the tasty food the wait staff hostess and waitress were attentive and prompt the space is small enough that on busy nights it could fill up quickly but the two handled the smallish crowd deftlyi will definitely be heading back if only to indulge in the künefe the oftmentioned phyllocheese pastry dish

SentimentText: The best Turkish food in the whole of the USA. My mother-in-law is from Turkey and we stop at every Turkish restaurant when we travel. This is by far the best we've had. Stuffed falafel in the salad was the perfect consistency; the mucver was crispy on the outside & deliciously soft inside; doner kebab was cooked nice & tender, and the beyti Adana had crispy, flaky lavash bread wrapped around the meat--original & delicious. Wish we lived in San Francisco--what a find!

SentimentText: Tuba was a solid, well-crafted Turkish restaurant experience. I came with a friend of mine and we used a groupon to order and share a few plates. Being Turkish myself, I jumped on the menu to try and get a variety of things so we could figure out what was best.The mucver (mooj-vare) was fantastic. For those who don't know, it's essentially zucchini and other random green vegetables mashed together and fried into a ball using an egg batter that's a little heavy on the dill. It reminded of me aunt's cooking and it might have actually been the highlight of the meal!We then had the hunkar begendi (bay-end-ee), which was a creamy pile of eggplant mush, heavy on garlic, with pieces of lamb in it. If you like eggplant, you should definitely get this dish. If you don't, avoid it all costs. Because you're really just eating delicious eggplant mush.Last, we had the mixed grill, which had a chicken kebab, lamb kebab, kofte kebab, adana kebab, and the world's tiniest single lamb chop. The tiny lamb chop of good, the kofte kebab standard, and the chicken/lamb kebab forgettable (as they usually are most everywhere). That said, the adana kebab was awesome. Really spicy all the way through the meat, flavorful, cooked just right. I'd go back here just for more adana kebab. Awesome.The services was Turkish-friendly and they made ice tea out of Turkish tea, which is why I was on a caffeine high until 2am. Overall, this might be the best Turkish restaurant in San Francisco right now.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Phenomenal experience overall and a ScoutMob discount to boot! Kept it simple with a falafel salad, which was great to share and scrumptious with feta filled falafel. Main entree was the lamb kebob, which the waiter claimed were the "best in the Bay" -- and they were delicious: seared and cooked medium, they cut like steak and didn't have anything really "lamby" about them. Finished off with oven-baked rice pudding: light and a perfect pallet cleaner. Not only was the food amazing, but the service was amazing; attentive and very quick.

SentimentText: I loved this restaurant. Had never heard anything about it-saw an Opentable 1000 restaurant score, and figured that I might as well try something new. (How many times can you go back to Luna Park?)The flatbread is off the charts good. Soft, chewy with wonderful accompaniments of sundried pesto butter and feta. I ordered two mezes: a falafel/hummus plate and the feta cheese and potato phyllo rolls. So good and filling. It is the perfect place to get soul warming food on a cold, wet San Francisco summer evening. The portions are HUGE. I had ended up taking back most of itI was stuffed after eating one falafel patty, a side salad and one phyllo roll. .My husband ordered the lentil soup, which is purported to be best in San Francisco and the chicken. He was stuffed too. He also had a beer.Final price tag: $50 for everything. Amazing quality of food and great portions. Guess what I am eating on Sunday night?

SentimentText: I understand some of the criticism here about service, but not really the complaints about the food. We had a large party (7 people) on a Friday night, and they took our reservation...but when we got to the restaurant they hadn't prepared for us to come and had to ask another table of two to move so that we could be accommodated. Not great planning on their part, but after waiting 15 minutes it worked out.After that, the service and food were top-notch. I loved the feta cheese rolls which were delicious, and we had the server select a couple of meat and veggie options for us to split family-style. The spicy lamb was amazing, as was the moussaka with eggplant.restaurant.com offers $100 for $50 coupons for this place (I think maybe other options too) so we got a really sweet deal when it came down to splitting the bill. The BYOB thing helped too, obviously, but that probably won't last once they get a license.All in all, I would highly recommend this place, but maybe would recommend going with a smaller group.

SentimentText: I am surprised to see the high reviews here.  The place has potential, but I'm not rating on that.  The restaurant was decently designed and service started out well, but food should be the ulitimate driver for this rating.  While it's great that you can bring your own wine for now, the food was good but not out of this world, nothing to be excited about necessarily.  There were two of us and our order took a really long time.  Our appetizer came out first and was cold - they gladly took it back (but don't they check it before it goes out?).  It took about another 30 minutes or so to see our entrees.  While our server was very kind and apologetic, it ruined the experience.  We observed other parties who got there after us had both their apps and entrees served. Perhaps they are working out those kinks, but seems to be a trend as seen in the other reviews.  It's really too bad that this was our first impression as we went in not having high expectations to begin with, only to have a nice meal with good service.  Not sure I will try this place again. Bummer.

SentimentText: Over the past 4 years of living in the City I've had the opportunity to try cuisines from all corners, and Turkish always finishes on the top of my list.  This is why I was excited to hear about this restaurant opening so close to my home. I made my first visit to Tuba a few nights after it opened as the third wheel to a couple that I'm friends with, and without a doubt, will be my go-to place when I'm craving some Turkish fare.The atmosphere was warm and inviting with decorations one could tell that some extra attention and care had been taken.   Our starters which we shared were the Ezme (my favorite) and a falafel salad.  The falafel was warm and crisp on the outside, but not dried out, and had a bit of melting goat cheese in the middle, a nice touch.My main course was the lamb chops which were grilled amazingly.  I also shared a little of an eggplant dish that I can't remember the name of.  I had Irmik for dessert.  It was a warm treat of pine nuts sauteed in butter mixed with cinnamon and semolina, all topped with a little vanilla ice cream. The dessert I ate was new to me and pretty good, but at that point I was already full.  Be careful not to fill up and overdo it on the unlimited bread they'll offer to bring you.  I skipped the Turkish coffee since I was headed to SFO for a red eye that night, but left Tuba more than satisfied and excited to return.Once their liquor license is approved, it can only get better when they can serve some nice selections from Kavaklidere, or an Efes in a frosty glass.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Merhaba Tuba! Welcome to my neighborhood; I've been waiting for you for soooo long!I can't begin to describe how excited I am about this place. When people ask me what I miss about Turkey (I moved to the US in 1994), my answer  always begins with the same duo: "I miss the Aegean Sea and I miss the food." I always add that I also miss Turkish hospitality. Well. The Aegean Sea remains far away, but Tuba brings to my adopted home, the Mission, both the food and the hospitality that I'd been missing. Reservations (in response to an earlier review): I made reservations on Opentable.com, and upon arriving at the restaurant (a little after 6 pm--I was rushing to get to a show that night), I realized I didn't need to. The place was empty when I arrived. I think more people began coming in around 6:30 or so. By the time I left the restaurant around 7:30 pm, the restaurant was full, but there were still tables available. My suggestion: if you can, use Opentable.com -- it's handy, has an iPhone app, and you get credit the more you use it.  Hospitality: My partner-in-crime wasn't there when I arrived at Tuba, so I stood there for a second, looking at the menu. The owner immediately noticed me and welcomed me in. As soon as I sat down, he asked if I would like some tea or coffee while I waited. We chatted a bit about his restaurant, and because he doesn't have his liquor license yet, he encouraged me to bring my own from the store at the end of the block if I needed some beer or wine with my meal. He mentioned he expects to get his license in the next two weeks (this was about a week ago). He was happy to provide a corkscrew or a bottle opener and glasses for us. Such a warm person. I immediately felt at home in this space, and getting to speak in Turkish with him was an added bonus. The food: My ultimate test of authenticity is the dolma. I can walk into a Middle Eastern café, take one look at the dolmas, and be able to tell whether they're from a can or homemade (sorry to say, folks, most of the time, they're from a can). A restaurant, of course, is different. I asked our waiter if they were homemade just in case, and they were...and they were almost as good as grandma's. Almost. My partner-in-crime, who apparently doesn't usually like dolma, ate all of his, so there you go. The other appetizers we got were the sigara börek and ezme (the regular kind, not the zucchini kind). The börek was great (careful with your first bite--it's hot!), and the ezme was out of this world. We tried in vain to stop ourselves from spreading the ezme on the delicious pide (not pita) bread so we didn't get too full. Well, we did get too full, and we weren't so hungry at 6 pm to begin with. Fortunately, we had ordered the mixed grill to share (the one-person version rather than the mixed grill for two). It came with lamb chop (fantastic!), chicken kebab, shish kebab, adana kebab, rice, and veggies (I think I'm forgetting one more kind of kebab on there). It was plenty of food for both of us after all the appetizers, and yet another affirmation that Oh. Yes. I do looooove meat on a skewer. With no room for dessert, I had to skip the irmik helvasi that I was looking forward to sampling. Next time! Just thinking about the menu makes my mouth water. There's so much variety and deliciousness on that menu that I just can't wait to return! Bonus points for Tuba: 1. As someone who learned English as a second language, and who is now an English teacher, I have an instinctive habit of recognizing typos and grammatical errors on menus, especially when they're not American restaurants. I saw no errors on Tuba's menu. 2. Wine-red walls always make me feel at home...so do beautiful dark wood furniture.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: First of all, location: far enough from Valencia to find parking.  In fact, we found street parking within two blocks. Ambiance: warm and welcoming. Service: impeccable. They cleared our silverware midway and wiped our table before dessert.  Dishes: we ordered ezme (crushed walnuts, pepper paste, etc.), lentil soup, moussaka, beyti adana (grilled lamb wrapped in lavash with yogurt and grilled pepper), and for dessert, kiinefe (delicious), Turkish coffee, and Turkish tea.  Each dish was well prepared and attractively presented.  The complimentary bread was served warm with  spicy butter/olives/feta cheese. We loved the decor of deep red walls, hanging lights, splashy abstract paintings, and unusually colorful salt and pepper shakers.  This is a perfect place for a date on a Friday night.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Just came home from our first meal at Tuba and I am still savoring the delicious flavors of the authentic Turkish food. The service is excellent:  we were greeted by the host himself and because it was still early and the restaurant hadn't yet filled up for the evening (it did!) we had a nice chat with him about Turkey (we've been there twice) and the extensive cuisine it boasts. The service was fine without being intrusive, and the ambience of the restaurant felt authentic. We asked our server for recommendations, and the suggestions did not disappoint, starting with the Turkish white wine, a house-made lemonade, and the large plate of cold mezes.  There were three of us, so we selected three main courses, each of which was delicious.  I can't remember their names, but one was a plate of small dumplings stuffed with ground beef, another was grilled shrimp with asparagus.  While Turkish food borrows from many cuisines, the flavors here were interesting and unique.  Definitely a be-back for us!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: At some point I think most frequent Yelper foodies have a crisis of confidence. It usually happens in the company of others. Perhaps you've just launched into a sotto voice diatribe about how not awesome the mole/falafel/burger/hip food of the moment you ordered is. It could be after a snooty aside about the played out decor or the indifferent service. The critical wheels of your brain are well lubricated with 30 weight haterade and you're already salivating over the next Yelp bomb you'll drop perhaps as soon as right then if you can punch out something appropriately pithy on your ninjaphone. You stop and wonder if your urge to disassemble your dining experience is, itself, crapping on your dining experience or (sometimes more importantly) the experience of your homies. Well, I'm here to say "funk that!" Top off the pretty hate machine with another quart of vitriolade and let it rip. Like I'm about to. The oh-so-soon to be missus wanted to give these guys 1 star. We could go with 1.5 stars, let's call it that. We'll round up to 2 thanks to our $25 of flat, unseasoned Turkish food for $12 Groupon and the two glasses of wine they comped us for the 52 minute wait between our salad and main courses. This place is pricey homes and doesn't really show out with anything to set it above your corner schwarma shop. In fact, we both ranked it a solid cut below the late night kabob cart (see NYC). Why? Lack of flavor! Dings - regular bread at the table - weird. Nothing specifically wrong with it but we were expecting pita and it didn't quite jive with the food. - cold dip thing tasted like... hmm, mostly nothing - Sheppard's salad was basically a Greek salad but ended up being a LOT of cucumbers, a few bits of tomato, red onion, 4 olives, and some parsley. - manti pasta was uber watery, bland, and chef boy-r-dee tasting with little or no sauce or taste beyond general ground beef - kabob sampler was the highlight, everything well cooked but somewhat under seasoned (a recurring theme)The worst gripes were the total lack of communication in the service. Almost an hour between salad and mains without any kind of communication in the interim sucks. After a few attempts to get information on when we could expect our food we were met with confusion ("did you get your salad yet?") and then lame excuses ("the pasta takes a long time to cook" what pasta takes an hour to cook?). Every restaurant can have bad kitchen nights and this might have been one of them. Our server did her best to recover and was gracious and apologetic but the stand out failure of our meal was how often we had to reach for the salt and pepper shakers just to make the food passable. I might expect that at a steak house but at a Turkish restaurant? I know a few things about Middle Eastern food and one of them is that lack of flavor and seasoning is not usually an issue. If I'm going to pay double what I'd pay at Truly Mediterranean I would like it to be at least slightly better as opposed to much worse. Remember kids, honesty goes both ways.  So don't fear to speak your mind.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Tuba occupies a space which has been the site of many a failed restaurant since I've lived in the neighborhood. However, judging from their food, service and ambiance -- and the fact that they've been continually busy since opening a few months ago -- I'm confident Tuba will be around for a while.The Mücver, pan fried zucchini patties with fresh dill, are superb, as is the Musakka, which I was thrilled to learn is vegetarian. The Patlican Salatasi -- grilled eggplant puree with bell pepper, tomato, garlic -- is also excellent. I was too full to try dessert (portions are substantial), but I will definitely be back to sample them.Service is deft, friendly and welcoming, and they've totally transformed the space; it's warm, inviting and beautiful.I smell a hit.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: When you tell the server multiple times that you're allergic to chilies, peppers, and all manner of spicy food, they should be able to recommend a safe option from the menu. Instead, I was told they could make anything without spices. So I ordered the Kafte Kebab... And it was definitely too hot for me when it arrived. I suspect it had red pepper or cayenne, but I couldn't tell for certain. :( This is why I give four stars instead of five.Fortunately one of my dining companions had ordered the "Stuffed Salmon with fume sauce over rice," and he was eying my kebab with entree envy, so we switched plates. This was one of the most fantastic Salmon dishes I've ever had the pleasure of eating. It's certainly not Turkish (I spent a month in Turkey and don't recall this dish being part of any traditional Turkish menu), but it's a nice option when you're struggling to communicate a food allergy in an ethnic setting.The appetizers, including the hummus and fried feta cheese, were delicious, as was the chocolate cake I had for desert. I would highly recommend Tuba to friends.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Over the past few years, I became addicted to Redwood City's New Kapadokia, one of the previous ventures of the fellows who started Tuba.  Living in the City, I wasn't going to complain about Turkish food being now a thirty minute WALK from my house rather than a thirty minute DRIVE -- so I decided to bring a date and check it out.  And in many ways, these guys have upped their game.The decor is nice; it creates a good ambience.  We brought our own bottle of wine (Tuba doesn't yet have their liquor license), but there's no corkage fee -- and the place was full last night, so I'm sure the liquor store a few doors down is running a tidy profit.  We ordered what ended up being far too much food, but we wanted to try as much as possible.  For appetizers, we got the Ezme (red pepper paste, which is the same as New Kapadokia's, and one of the sources of my addiction to that place) and the Feta Prawns, which were excellent; the sauce they came with made for great bread dipping.  We got two entrees and a salad.  The Beyti (meat wrapped in lavash bread) was quite good, and the lamb chops expertly grilled.  The salad was merely decent; I think it came with breaded prawns.  Dessert was something that had pine nuts in it, and it came topped with ice cream; I'm still trying to figure out how we managed room in our stomachs to eat it.  The staff was quite attentive and made sure we had plenty of bread and water.  We came in late, so the head manager chatted with us for a while at the end of the evening.  All in all, an easy decision of five stars, and I'll most certainly be back!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I'm always impressed by a place that is friendly and helpful, but largely gets out of your way so you can enjoy a meal with friends.Went here on a Friday night with a group 13 deep.  We had a reservation but not all of our people showed up on time.  They seated us anyways and were really patient with us as we got settled and waited for people to arrive.  Even when we were kind of blocking the doorway, they didn't get irate and let us take our time.  I know how unwieldy a large group like that is, so I really appreciated their patience with us.The food was delicious!!  I don't know that I've had much other Turkish food to compare it to, but it was good.  We got the "Patlcan salatas grilled" eggplant puree appetizer on my side of the table which was really good.  Large chunks of garlic yummmm.  The bread and butter were really tasty too.  For my entree I got the beef ravioli (I don't remember what it's called, started with an M) in some sort of tomato yogurt sauce.  It was so good I ate it all, which is pretty rare for lil ol' me!  Also had the Turkish pilsner Effe, which was pretty good as well.Once our large and unwieldy group had finished eating, we stayed on chatting (part of this large group were six high school friends, some of whom hadn't seen each other in 8 years) for a good 20 min.  Which could be kind of a jerk move if the place was busy, but there wasn't anyone waiting for a table by that point.  The wait staff never rushed us or asked us to move along, again I really appreciate that sort of thing.To summarize: Yummy food, good atmosphere, friendly (but not overbearing) staff.  We stayed here for at least 2.5 hours and enjoyed every minute of it!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Wonderful Turkish food with a great wait staff. This place is good for a relaxed date or meal with friends. Ok.. do you like lamb? yes?  You will LOVE their lamb.  no? why?  you don't like gamey meat?  You will LOVE their lamb.  Oh my god!  Thank you. Finally.  A place that knows how to prepare and cook lamb.  There is not one hint of gaminess.  It is simply delicious.  The lamb chops are marinated for 3 days and oh so delish.  I had the lamb shank special, and it was literally falling off the bone - fork tender and delicious.  So so so delicious.  Did I say try the lamb?  Really.. if you read any of my reviews, because I know how lamb is "supposed"to taste (like it does here) I have a hard time eating it in places that don't know how to prepare it. The falafel with the goat cheese center... YUM!  oh so good. My brother really liked the Cevizli Ezme (walnut red pepper paste)I also highly recommend the crabcake, falafel, and borek (boregi). The lentil soup is wonderful, fresh & hit the spot. I wouldn't say it is the 'best" but I will definitely order it again.  The feta prawns I thought were ok- my mom loved them. The icli kofte (kibbeh) was not crispy on the outside as it should be, but had good flavor.  I would order it again hoping that it was an off batch. The Mucver (zucchini fritters) also had great flavor but was too wet in the center both times I ordered them.  It may be a consistency you like, but I prefer it them a bit more dry & with a little bit of crispiness on the outside.  For dessert we got the baklava, Pyramid Noisette Chocolate, and Kunefe. My favorite was the pyramid. The kunefe was so good. The baklava was a bit dry & I was told that it depends on the batch of baklava, since it is made in house.  This may be a factor.. ask if  the baklava is moist or dry that day :-) I can't wait to go back!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Friends of mine took me to Tuba on Sunday.  It is cozy inside, with an intimate feel.  Like another reviewer, we were greeted right away with a smile and quickly seated. Service was excellent.  The manager waited on us at first and suggested the Turkish beer.  Very tasty!  We started with the Tuba cold platter.  Delicious!  I recognized the humus and the rolled grape leaves, but not much else.  Didn't matter - very yummy.  Our meals were great as well.  I played is safe and ordered the lamb kabob.  Done perfectly to my medium (pink!) order.  The lamb had great flavor!  And the vegetables were very nicely grilled (not barely seared and raw like so many places).  And the rice had wonderful flavor as well.  My friends order the special that night - lamb shank is too was excellent.  I went for it and had dessert.  The rice pudding is GREAT!Final comment - the service was super; attentive without being intrusive and the meal was timed beautifully.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: Tuba is a wonderful authentic Turkish spot. The mezes brought me back to the wonderful flavors of Istanbul, with a few using appropriate California twists. For example, a salad including falafel filled with goat cheese and a little chopped avocado in the mix. Nothing wrong with bringing local ingredients to liven up an already great green salad. I went opening night and was impressed by the quality of service...I was happy to leave a little room for "kinks", but it wasn't necessary. One of the owners checked in with us several times--his warmth and sense of humor gives this place a family-feel. I had the adana kebab and asked for a little extra spice; it was cooked perfectly, full of flavor and not dry at all. My friends had the mixed grill and I tried a bit of the lamb chop which melted in my mouth.  I look forward to going back and trying some other goodies I miss from my days of living in Turkey.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I was really happy with Tuba and don't just think it was "A-OK" but "A-OK!" (said with enthusiasm).  I was sad that there wasn't a large man playing a tuba when we entered as I had imagined, but the food was good and very Turkish-esk.I enjoyed my glass of wine and the goat-cheese-stuffed-falafel salad.  I would highly recommend this salad.I ordered the shrimp scampi but was served the shrimp kabobs.  No problem!  The main difference is the sauce and they were marvelous about bringing me the sauce on the side.  Chris L. got a ground lamb dish which he said looked, tasted and acted exactly like many a dish he enjoyed while in Turkey last September.  So, I guess this place is authentic!

SentimentText: My first experience with Turkish food and I'm smitten.I went here last week with my new Turkish friend who took it upon himself to introduce me to this amazing cuisine. We started out with Dolmas, which I have had before and enjoy, and Icli Kofte which were DELICIOUS! I've been thinking about them ever since and can't wait to have them again. Basically they're made of spicy ground lamb breaded and fried into the shape of a small football. My mouth is watering.From there we moved to the main courses: Hunkar Begendi and Beyti Adana. The first one is unlike anything else we have in America. It's basically mashed potatoes made out of eggplant. I was perplexed. And of course, it's topped with delectable lamb chunks. The second entree was again lamb, wrapped in dough with yogurt and a tomato sauce.Lastly, dessert. Obviously, I was getting pretty full, but if I was gonna go Turkish, I was gonna go big. So for dessert we got Kunefe. I ate it, loved it, and then asked what it was....CHEESE! Baked stringy cheese covered in honey sauce and pistachios. Amazing!

SentimentText: This was my second time to Tuba and I was even more impressed than on my first visit.  We were a large group (9 people) and the servers were very attentive and helpful.  Our main server was friendly with a nice smile, something that isn't necessary, but certainly helps make the dining experience extra enjoyable.  Stuffed falafel salad was delicious, and the hummus and dolmas were some of the best I've had in the city.  Extra bonus points for the following:1) We had a birthday in our group and they surprised us with a lovely chocolate dessert.    2) The woman at the table next to our accidentally knocked her glass of wine over and it fell to the floor and broke.  Not only did the servers clean it immediately (as would be expected), but they brought the patron a full new glass of wine as well (really nice touch!).I definitely recommend Tuba, the food and service was great, and it worked really well for a group dinner.

SentimentText: A welcome addition to the Mission that I hope will continue to thrive despite it's cursed retail space.The salad portions are enormous! My husband and I each ordered one as a starter. The Pistachio-crusted Shrimp Salad was  tossed in a spicy vinagrette, while the Falafel Salad, our favorite perhaps in part to the soft goat cheese melted in each of the 4 falafel balls.  (For a lighter dining experience I  recommend splitting salad orders with a friend).As an entree, my husband ordered a traditional Turkish dish called Hunkar Begendi which is a smoky eggplant puree drizzled with a tomato sauce and topped with small cubes of stewed lamb.  Although the flavor of the dish was remarkable, the lack of texture made it less interesting, but was defintitely worth experiencing.  I played it safe with their Stuffed Salmon dish, which isn't actually "stuffed' at all, but instead topped with pan fried onions (and something else?).  This dish was both attractive, cooked perfectly and tasty and I would recommend it to salmon lovers.Tuba Restaurant is rather small so I strongly encourage making a reservation.  The staff does their best to accommodate walk-ins, but the result is too many tables which we all know equates to over-crowding and undue chaos.  I'm hoping they'll remove a few tables soon and correct this one downfall going forward in hopes to teach us each us all to plan ahead with a reservation that is worth the wait

SentimentText: This place is a hidden gem. Located near many bars within walking distance and a nice romantic but not too romantic setting I will surely be back.The Içli Kofte ( spiced ground sirloin in a crispy bulgur shell) was off the hook ... so delicious I will get this again. The hummus was a little off for my tastes... it was REALLY creamy tasting ... almost concentrated tasting. The lamb kabobs were some of the best I have had.They were out of like 3 different dishes and after the waitress or kitchen made the mistake of letting us order something they were out of .. they ended up comping that entree. THAT is how you run a successful business. The wine is not overpriced, the ambiance is nice, the food was delicious and the service although a little off was still courteous and accommodating.This is a new place... show them some love.

SentimentText: Okay so here' s the deal.  i was struggling between 3 and 4 stars because i really really enjoyed the food - but i wasn't sure if the novelty of it really made it special or if it was the food itself.  The matti and moussakah were really really good - like 5 star good.  But the warm plate starter had a few bland apps which could have been twisted into something uniquely san francisco and flavorful.  the service was timely and excellent, though often we were confused by who was our real server (3 really nice people helped us.) parking is tough but knew this going into it so no star reduction for parking. 3 or 4....humph am i tough critic? oh all right i'll give it 4.  but only because damian says so.

SentimentText: I really wanted to love this restaurant.  The location, ambience and decor are all terrific.  The portions were large however they truly lacked flavor.  (Do they not have ANY spices or even salt and pepper in that kitchen??)  I paid $2 for hot tea, which was served in a tiny shot glass -- totally impossible to pick up because it was boiling hot and there was no handle.  We ordered hummus and it came with a loaf of bread to put it on -- much too heavy.  I asked about pita bread and they brought tiny pita chips about the size of a dime.  The pistachio-encrusted shrimp in the salad was over-cooked and heavy.  The servers and host  were incredibly nice and very friendly and helpful but all-in-all...Sorry-- it was a huge disappointment and because there are so many other places to try, I doubt that I will give Tuba another chance...

SentimentText: We live nearby & have been meaning to try it for a while; we finally ended up going because of a Groupon, and weren't disappointed!After considering several different tasty-sounding dishes, we settled on the Stuffed Falafel Salad, a huge plate of tasty greens in light Mediterranean dressing with tangy avocado salsa, with three giant falafels filled with melted goat cheese.  For entrees, I had the sauteed chicken, which is like a hearty Mediterranean chicken stew, served in a piping hot bowl with mushrooms, olives, and cheese in a super flavorful tomato/herb broth.  Served with rice and salad on the side; try dumping the rice into the stew for a risotto effect.  My boyfriend had the, Hünkar Beendi, pureed eggplant with mozzarella cheese topped with lamb cubes.  Also very tasty!A word of caution - they tend to be very busy, especially on the weekend, so it doesn't hurt to make a reservation.  We went around 7:30 on a Friday evening without & waited 40 minutes.  Service was a little bit slow, but not egregiously so.We'll be back!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I'm a fan of Tuba. I was here with a friend on Tuesday night, and they were surprisingly busy for a weeknight. Nonetheless, the service was attentive and friendly.We ordered several items from the menu, and all were very good. The kunefe dessert is distressingly addictive. (Having learned today that the chef worked at New Kapadokia in Redwood City, which is a favorite of mine, I'm not surprised by the yuminess.) In addition, prices are very reasonable, especially for the neighborhood. My only regret is the lack of elma çay on the  menu. Even still, I'll be back early and often!As of this week they still don't have a liquor license, so corkage is free. I'm not in a hurry for that to change, but I assume it will eventually.

SentimentText: This place is a great new (to me, at least) Mission spot.I searched Yelp for a place I had not yet been in the Mission for a reunion with friends I had gone way-too-long without a dinner with and found Tuba.  The menu looked great so we gave it a try.We appreciated the varied wine menu and ordered a $20 bottle of wine along with the Cold Appetizer plate, the zucchini cakes, crab cakes and falafel and goat cheese salad - so much food for three of us and so tasty.  The cold dips were a great selection, the bread is similar to what I have had at other Mediterranean places (tho I do prefer pita) and was bountiful, the crab cakes were VERY yummy, and the falafel, both bites with the goat cheese and without, were exceptional. The only complaint was how oily the food was, but damn, it tasted great, and it was nice not to be rushed as we dipped and ate through out treats.I'd highly recommend this place for a tapas-like dinner, though I also want to go back to try some of their tasty sounding dinner plates.Well priced, great service, and nice variation.  Can't wait to return.

SentimentText: PROS:  Flavorful food with an authentic Turkish atmosphere.CONS: Rather small space, call ahead for reservations.Four of us went to dinner at Tuba. We called around 6:00 for a reservation and were able to book that evening at 8:15pm. The restaurant is still relatively new as of this post (opened in December 2009), so this could change as the restaurant matures.AMBIENCEA warm and cozy Mediterranean feel. Dark rich colors (deep reds, browns, etc.), give it a warm feeling while the various vases and art throughout made it feel authentic. There are about 6-8 four-tops running along each side of the restaurant which can be pushed together for larger parties. And there were about 3-5 two tops that ran along the center. Point being, it's relatively small. SERVICEThe night we were there, they only had 2 waiters, however, we never felt like we were waiting for too long to receive attention. We asked for one special request which was promptly served. Our water and wine glasses were refilled and our plates were removed quickly upon finishing. FOODThe food was very tasty. We ordered the hummus, which oddly didn't come with pita or flat bread of any kind. (This was our special request). We shared a few dishes including the hot appetizer sampler, Greek salad, ground sirloin and chicken kabobs. Portions were hearty and all tasted good.PRICEThere are a lot of options depending how much you want to spend. Appetizers and salads can run between $6 - $15. Entrees are the more 'normal' price of $12-$20. Note at the time of this review they don't have their liquor license so they are allowing you to bring in your own bottles of wine (there's a liquor store around the corner) without a corkage fee. [read: go today for a good deal on dinner ! ]  :)
Label: Genuine
text1: pros flavorful food with an authentic turkish atmospherecons rather small space call ahead for reservationsfour of us went to dinner at tuba we called around 600 for a reservation and were able to book that evening at 815pm the restaurant is still relatively new as of this post opened in december 2009 so this could change as the restaurant maturesambiencea warm and cozy mediterranean feel dark rich colors deep reds browns etc give it a warm feeling while the various vases and art throughout made it feel authentic there are about 68 fourtops running along each side of the restaurant which can be pushed together for larger parties and there were about 35 two tops that ran along the center point being its relatively small servicethe night we were there they only had 2 waiters however we never felt like we were waiting for too long to receive attention we asked for one special request which was promptly served our water and wine glasses were refilled and our plates were removed quickly upon finishing foodthe food was very tasty we ordered the hummus which oddly didnt come with pita or flat bread of any kind this was our special request we shared a few dishes including the hot appetizer sampler greek salad ground sirloin and chicken kabobs portions were hearty and all tasted goodpricethere are a lot of options depending how much you want to spend appetizers and salads can run between 6  15 entrees are the more normal price of 1220 note at the time of this review they dont have their liquor license so they are allowing you to bring in your own bottles of wine theres a liquor store around the corner without a corkage fee read go today for a good deal on dinner

SentimentText: I can't speak for everyone else's experience with their service, but we thought everyone was very nice and helpful - we thought it was pretty entertaining when another table's waiter commented on how "yummy" our food looked.  Plus, Tuba is the only restaurant that allows you to bargain for reservations.  A snippet of our phone conversation:Me: Do you have a table for two available tonight at 7:00?Tuba: I'm sorry sir, we are really busy tonight - does 6:30 work?Me: No, that'll be too early, I'm coming straight from work...Tuba: How about 8:00?  We have a great table for two at that time...Me: Hmmm...well, I am pretty hungry...how about 7:00?Tuba: Sure, I see an opening - see you at 7:00!Service aside, this is the best Mediterranean I've had in SF (sorry La Mediterranee - but you've had that spot on my list for 3 years now).  Dinner started out on a low point - we had the dolmas, which were pretty blah.  Between our shrimp kebabs and salmon, both our main courses were excellent - the salmon had an explosion of flavors I don't usually associate with salmon or med food.  Finally, kunefe for dessert was absolutely amazing - it's proves that if baklava ever met sweet cheese and then had an affair with pistachos, they'd have delicious kids.  Wait scratch that metaphor, it sounds creepy and doesn't make sense...you would actually end up with two sort of tasty desserts instead of single really delicious one.    Anyways, the only downsides of this place are that it's a bit cramped/small and parking sucks - but they're both small prices to pay for some tasty Turkish food.  I'll definitely be back soon!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I've traveled to Turkey five times the past five years, including a stint of five months the last time there.  My number one love and activity there has been the food.  I really wanted to love this place, but it is unfair for me to expect what you would experience food-wise in Turkey here in San Francisco, but I can't help to compare.  All things considered, I thought the food at Tuba was good, the service very good.I was so excited to try this place and never would have known about it had I not seen their Groupon offer (thank you for offering up one as adding incentive to try and making your presence know in SF).  The name doesn't exactly imply Turkish, so never would have known.  I've walked by this place a few times in the past and had no idea.  I'm always on the lookout for Turkish restaurants, especially with menus that go beyond kebap and baklava.  Tuba certainly does.The front of house staff were super friendly and accommodating.  We didn't have a reservation and the place was packed, but they were able to seat us anyway.  We had a few appetizers, entree, and desert.Food-wise, the highlight was the Kunefe with a little tea (in the little curvy Turkish tea glasses at that) to wash it down.  I never had Kunefe like this in Turkey.  The Tuba version had generous amount of cheese filling really made it stand out.Overall, yes this place is worth a try, the food is good, service friendly, ambiance ok, but if you have experienced Turkish food in Turkey and are expecting the same, you may be a little disappointed.

SentimentText: I can't speak more highly of Tuba. I went last night for my birthday and the owner greeted me himself. My table of 10 was plied with goodies and attention for the remainder of the evening. I had never met the owner before but everyone at my table hugged him as we left. Yep, it's that kind of place. And he's that kind of guy. Both sampler platters are incredible (cold and hot), as are all shish kebabs, and both salads (goat cheese stuffed falaffel? Yes please). The Turkish pilsner is crisp and delicious and they actually have some really decent wines on the list. All in all, a really great mid-price restaurant.

SentimentText: We enjoyed our dining experience here last Saturday before taking in the Marga Gomez show down around the corner.   I'll get the cons out of the way first and explain why I took off a star:  My girlfriend remarked that our waitness looked like she could have used a good meal herself, and that she seemed rather listless and unattentive.  I had to ask her twice for lemon for my drink, the yummy bread was removed from our table to make room for our salads without asking us if we would like to keep it.  Finally, when my girl friend paid with a credit card, she noted that it was left unattended for quite a while at the station where anyone could have picked it up.  She did tell a man who said he was the owner and he was quite apologetic for this having happened.  Now the pros:  Delicious Turkish food of which we had, between us, a mixed grill shishkabob, a prawn salad with pistascios and mango salsa (could have used more of this!), another salad with chopped tomatos and cucumbers, a grilled steak, both of the entrees came with very flavorful rice, and we both split a creme brule'and a hazelnut noisette pyramid for dessert.  Five stars for the food, but a scarce three stars for service.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: We checked out Tuba on opening night, expecting their to be opening night kinks... but no.  We loved everything about it.  The food was amazing, the service was perfect.  The waiter know what he was talking about even the doors had opened for the first time just two hours earlier.  Prices are completely reasonable.I recommend the mixed grill... lamb, chicken and other tasty turkish meat preparations.  All were perfectly cooked.  The head guy was friendly gracious, visiting our table numerous times, and bringing a treat that we didn't order.  The apps were so good, so flavorful, that even though I was full I couldn't stop eating.  We were with a friend who has lived in Turkey and she marveled at how authentic everything was.Another great dish is the grilled chicken with a savory sauce of tomato, garlic, pepper, onion, etc.  It was perfect, as were the lamb chops, which are so easy to over or under cook but these were just right.The bread, herbed butter, and tomato garlic spread were so good that you have to be careful to save room 'cause you're not going to want to leave anything on your plate.The atmosphere is elegant but you can definitely come as you are, it's  not stuffy at all.  You just want to sit down and eat.  It's a very cozy place, the kind of spot that's equally good for dates, family gatherings, friends getting together, etc.On a block that has had numerous restaurants of varying degrees of success, it's great to have something this good that doesn't break the bank.Highly recommended.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I had the chance to try out Tuba because my friend purchased me a Coupon over one of those community coupon like buy w/ me sites.. kind of like a Groupon Site... so, my date and I decided to go there after a long day of shopping. We were greeted very poorly at the door by the hostess. She treated us like we were vagrants since we had the coupon, and she knew nothing about it. She then calls a manager, didn't even offer to seat us, and the manager acted confused. So I tried to explain to them that I have this coupon, and they may check with their sources. So She goes and calls the boss, and then comes back much nicer, and seats us. What that shows to me is that they have poor communication in their restaurant management. I think it all started off with the wrong vibe and the way they treated us. I don't know if it's because my date was African American or maybe simply because they weren't familiar with the coupon deal, but they were not very nice to us at all, and at no point did I feel welcome.We sit down, and proceed to order food. The cold appetizer platter was well presented and delicious, bread was very good.The Entres were huge, simply too much food for one person to eat. We got the Eggplant puree with lamb cubes, which was mediocre at best. My salad dish had giant Falafels but they didn't taste very fresh or flavorful. I couldn't finish any of it, so we packed it up for the dog.Decor was nice, food was generally well presented, though flavors were very mediocre since I've had phenomenal MiddleEastern food.. If you go to Shalizar or even Alibaba however the hostess' unfriendly demeanor really ruined our experience. I will not return.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: This was place was Ok.  Met a friend for an early dinner.  The menu is pretty standard - there were a few surprises. For example, an avocado salsa on one of the salads and the pistachio encrusted prawns.  Being it was our first time at the restaurant, we decided to go basic with the cold appetizer platter, the sauteed shrimp in the pepperoncini sauce, and a side of the falafel. We also ordered a couple of glasses of wine.  I'd give more stars for the ambiance, decor, and all over set-up.  Tuba does have a nice, cozy vibe.  Even romantic.  The artwork is an interesting choice - my friend had just had her eyes dilated and wondered if the paintings she saw were the result of her slightly blurred version. To start they offer complimentary bread accompanied by a nondescript red aioli type item, a few chunks of feta, and one olive.  The bread was my favorite part of the meal.  The server  indicated that they make it fresh daily.  The feta was nice and my friend and I split the one olive. The dip was flavorless.We waited quite awhile for our wine - it was early - three servers - not a lot of tables. We caught our server's attention and inquired about the wine --- it ended-up arriving with the meal. Everything came at the same - the hot and cold dishes - which is one of my peeves.  Plus, there wasn't ample space for all of the dishes.  I understand that we ordered all small plates, but they could've asked about the delivery pattern.  Service, despite the wait, was still friendly and personable.  Now for the food. The platter consisted of dolmas,  hummus, ezme, an eggplant salad, spinach dip, a thick yogurt, a caviar dip, and a white bean salad.  The portions were typical.  The food was 50/50. Overall,  I've had better in other Turkish restaurants and homemade by Turkish friends.  The best items were the hummus, the eggplant salad, the thick yogurt, and spinach dip. The falafel were nothing special and for me, the shrimp were overcooked.  The sauce was Ok - I wanted more zip.  The food pricing was fine.  The wine was also reasonably priced.  i wouldn't go back - I didn't get enough flavor nor that mom and pop feel on the plate that I so appreciate in these types of restaurants.
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: As a huge fan of Park Gyro, we heard that Tuba was opening and wanted to try it for ourselves.  What a delight. A warm homemade bread with flavored butter was set before us right away.  We decided to order dishes that we had not tried before since we were used to eating the wonderful kebabs at Park Gyro. I ran into my Turkish friends who suggested we order the "Tuba Cold Appetizer Plate" which was a great sampler of all the appetizers.  The Patlcan salatas grilled eggplant puree, bell pepper tomato garlic on the appetizer sampler was just delicious. The Hummus pureed garbanzo beans, lemon tahini sauce was good,( but better at Park Gyro in my opinion). The Mercimek Kofte lentils, parsley, green onions, bulgur was quite tasty. Kabak Ezme zucchini, dill, mint, yogurt light garlic was light and also yummy. Piyaz white bean salad with green onions, tomato and tahini vinegar lemon sauce was very nice, but the Ezme crushed walnuts, pepper paste, tomato paste, garlic, cumin was too spicy for my palate. I really, really enjoyed the Haydari fresh dill, mint, thick yogurt, light garlic and wish I could make it myself!For our entree, we shared Hünkar Beendi pureed eggplant with mozzarella cheese topped with lamb cubes. The eggplant had such a great smoky & creaminess that was so smooth and together with the tasty lamb cubes, it was really delicious. A very nice surprise.For dessert, Ali (owner and chef) especially made a Künefe Two layers of kadayf (shredded fillo dough) filled with sweet cheese, baked toperfection and served with homemade syrup and pistachio nut that was just out of this world!!!  Finished the entire plate. It was great to see Ali go around to each table to ask his patrons how their dinner was that evening. It left a very good feeling. The decor was very nice in warm tones of red and touches of Turkish decor. Noise level was a little loud. Service was excellent. Everyone was so friendly.  I want to go back with more friends to try more dishes!
Label: Genuine

SentimentText: I'm a little surprised by the glowing reviews on here about Tuba.  Maybe we just had bad luck, but our experience wasn't all that great. First of all, I give them one star for finally occupying the deserted storefront that has been empty for the last few years, after the last Italian restaurant shut their doors. They also did a good job making it look nice - think red walls and dark, rich wood, which earns them another star. The appetizer platter we ordered (and falafel) were also super yummy, so thumbs up for all of that.  The rest, however, was somewhat disappointing.  First of all, while not in a hurry, our main courses took far too long to arrive - conspicuously so.  And, when they did arrive, my veggie kabobs were cold (as if they had been sitting out for at least a half hour).  My friends' dishes were similarly disappointing. The stuffed eggplant was only so-so, and they were out of the vegetarian moussaka that we tried to order. I would maybe give them another chance after they've had a chance to work out some of the kinks.

Headed back soon for that hot fried appetizer sampler thing...
